[h1][b]TEKKEN 7![/b] Look, I made it back home! I'm up here with the [i][b]right[/b][/i] folks! [/h1]

Every time I‚Äôm up here, it‚Äôs like a choir of angels singing

[h3][b]‚Äúahhhhh.‚Äù[/b][/h3]

Ain‚Äôt no [i]ridiculous looking running animations because of the arbitrary implementation of meter in[b] yet another case of the encroaching homogenization against unique systems. 
[/b][/i] Ain‚Äôt there no chip damage‚Äîbut we [i]still got ours![/i] No particle effects out here be jumping out at you‚Äîonly not too much, not too little; don‚Äôt nobody be having chip damage to they eyes up here!

Ain‚Äôt no ESG hair-having characters getting they own trading cards up here. Ain‚Äôt there no more anti-consumer things jumping off neither, like [i]releasing 5 broken DLC characters in a row with [b]nerfs already planned for them[/b], or implementing a premium currency shop for legacy costumes [b]post-release in order to dodge negative reviews[/b]‚Äî[/i]‚Äòcuz they already got the money they needed from us up here.

These people up here are respectful‚Äîenjoying themselves. [i]How beautiful![/i]  They use their [i]‚Äúadvanced-ancient-secret‚Äù[/i] to stay together. [i]How beautiful![/i] 

[h2][b]TEKKEN 7. [/b][i]It‚Äôs TEKKEN. It‚Äôs where a real player wants to be. God Bless America & God Bless the Middle Class. üá∫üá∏üëç[/i][/h2]

With friends and family sitting in the same room with no internet! The original Dark Tekken has spoken! :) Good bye to this shit! ... Update! Now that part 8 came out. It's the same old crap. Can't find someone to challenge because they block people from playing the game. Because of that, I won't be buying part 8. The gaming world has been corrupted and is all about money and not people or having fun. I'm going back to the original way of playing. Sorry to all those who don't know what real gaming or having fun is. :)

Edit: The only game better than Tekken 7 is Tekken 8!!!! 

This game has no competition for being the best fighting game on PC. One character in this game has more depth than 10 Shotos in SFV

I'm a hardcore Feng main, I've played him for 60 hours. Just one single character for 60 hours and guess what? I have barely any knowledge of him! I know what most move's inputs are but that's about it. I can't do 1 dash 1 df 4,2,1+2, his staple ender. I can't add BT mixups into my natural gameplan. But I CAN spend hours in the lab perfecting my play and getting to the next level, the next rank, to beat someone else who is also on a similar journey. Maybe in 250 hours of Feng I will know him well enough to confidently say I'm good with him and could maybe win a tournament. And then ya look at the roster and what do you know? There are 40 more characters, all with the same insane level of depth as Feng, or more. Feng is a simple character to learn and he has 99 moves! Lei Wulong has the most in the game at like 160!!! But more realistically a character like Akuma can take months of practice to perfect. Heihachi? You need to learn to wavedash, backdash, electrics (frame perfect input of FDF1), and soooo much more. The only characters remotely similar to each other are the Mishimas, with their fF3, electrics, wavedashing, twin pistons, etc. I only said "remotely similar" as opposed to copy paste which is so insanely far from realistic.

Now look at SFV. My main man Gill has like, 10 unique moves. And only half of them are actually real as they're just Fire and Ice versions. Characters like Kage, Akuma, Ryu, Ken, Dan, Oni, all have pretty much the same movesets except for 4-5 moves. SHOTOS ARE COPY PASTE. They are pretty much only distinguished by frames. Yeesh...
Why is this game not on sale for Bandai's Lunar New Year sale? It's because 8 still needs some work.

With absolute certainty, I recommend Tekken 7. 

My rage and vengeance finally have an outlet where I can release some stress. 
This game is a true test of skill. No potions, no cowardice, and no cheap tricks/spells.

It is a damn shame that sewage waste such as Overwatch, Apex Legends, Dead by Daylight and other similar games exist. An endless cycle of soulless action and Acedia designed for the masses.

In Tekken 7 matches are going to vary from difficulty and at times may be unforgiving. It only gets stable through learning and timing. One wrong move and everything is over. Only through skill and patience can victory be achieved.

Playing Tekken 7 brings me nostalgia of playing older games such as Starcraft: Broodwar due to the difficulty and how  the mechanics relied on multiple actions rather than one single command.


I do not know what the future holds but I will conclude by saying Tekken 7 is a legendary masterpiece.

Tekken 7 is an absolute masterpiece in the world of fighting games! From its stunning graphics to its fluid gameplay mechanics, every aspect of this game is top-notch. The character roster is diverse and each fighter feels unique, offering endless hours of replayability. The story mode is engaging and immersive, drawing players deeper into the rich lore of the Tekken universe. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer to the series, Tekken 7 offers something for everyone, making it a must-have title in any gamer's collection. I can't recommend it enough. 

Recommended to play 5/5

Tekken 7 is very much Tekken, exactly like you've always known it.
Luckily the game knows how to get maximum gain out of seemingly minimal additions, like the flashy Rage Arts, tactical Power Crushes and surprisingly spectacular presence of Street Fighter icon Akuma. But due to the pretentious and disappointing single-player content it will never be a classic.

+ Gameplay and Combo mechanics are Really Good.
+ Characters are Much More Balanced

             [CONS]
- Bad Online Slow and Laggy.
- Loading took ages to load.

- There still few Character Which I Consider Broken or I should say Overpower Like Akuma, Leo,Howarang,Nina,Geese. Few of them only Spam you don't even get a chance to hit and few of them will take your whole health in one combo.

[h3] My favourite fighting game series and yeah, it's still good ole TEKKEN [/h3]

[b]This entry's got:[/b]
[i]- Sexy graphics
- Beautiful arenas
- Awesome music
- Large diverse cast
- Many interesting and surprising guests (even Negan from TWD, so wild)
- Cool story mode bro (srsly so awesome that they added a guest character to the story)
- The cinematic into gameplay transitions in story mode, are just *chef's kiss*, perfect
- TEKKEN's on brand weird and funny character cutscenes
- Loads of customization options
- Tight controls and smooth performance, awesome PC port
- Fun satisfying combos and an impressive array of badass moves
- And you can even view cutscenes and artworks from all the previous games![/i]

Negatives:
- Story mode's journalist narrator was honestly hard to listen to, very monotone
- Playable Kazumi doesn't have a Devil form like Kazuya.., would be cool, just saying..

While T3 and T5 are my favourites in the series, I consider this game to sit up there with them, it's truly a great entry, well deserving of it's long reign

Whether you're a casual player looking for some quick thrills or a hardcore competitor seeking the ultimate challenge, Tekken 7 delivers an unforgettable fighting experience that's sure to keep you coming back for more.

As a fighting game addicted this is by far my favorite one. I grew up enjoying fighting games since 3rd Strike and Tekken 5 but Tekken 7 was the one to make me really want to get into it.

By the time I'm writing this review, Tekken 8 is already out and exploding in success leaving its antecessor to rot quickly, and I'm writing this review as a way to say goodbye.

Even if this review finds you in an era where T7 has already became a relic, it's still worth the experience due to how great is the personality of this game and how expressive it is in terms of design and gameplay. Definitely a game that will leave a mark in history of fighting games communities and development.

DLCs are a great part of this game (be it a good thing or a bad thing) and I wouldn't recommend you buying a dead game without them. Guest characters is a great example and is something T7 excels at, throwing punches against Akuma and Geese is already crazy enough, but when you add Noctis to the equation you suddenly find yourself in an anime fight, just to play against Negan from TWD in the next match and not be able to stop thinking how badass this character is in the game.

Akuma and Geese already blew my mind regarding how they feel like your are playing their respective games without feeling like you are not playing Tekken (there is some controversy about that), but Negan and Noctis I actually got to know AFTER T7 and I was perplexed on how similar they are in the game compared to their own respective universe. The best cross over game I've ever seen.

I'm extremely thankful to the experiences this game provided me and I wish I had just a little more time with it.
good game, especially if you the pro player like me

Something about this one feels smoother than previous installments of Tekken. Movements look and feel better (not that the others were bad). If you're looking for another great Tekken experience look no further.

TEKKEN 7 on Steam provides an immersive and competitive fighting experience accessible to a wide audience. Its integration with the Steam platform offers seamless multiplayer matchmaking and community features. The game's stunning graphics and smooth gameplay mechanics shine on PC, delivering crisp visuals and responsive controls. Steam Workshop support allows players to access a wealth of user-generated content, from custom costumes to mods, enhancing replayability. While occasional connectivity issues and optimization concerns may arise, TEKKEN 7 on Steam remains a definitive choice for fighting game enthusiasts seeking intense battles and global competition in the digital realm.

*edit: game is fully playable on Keyboard(actually easier) but you can't use it huge LAN Tournaments/Consoles.

Learning and playing this game is an incredible chore, especially when compared to it's younger brother, Tekken 8. 

For one, there is no proper tutorial to this game. Nothing to tell you how the combos work, when to use certain universal moves, and the likes. They pretty much throw you in there, and you're supposed to figure out how to play against all these other players who have many years of experience. They gate frame data behind a paywall, and learning what you can or cannot do while actively fighting in game is exceedingly difficult. Certain animations are also atrociously ambiguous, making moves look different than their actual hit properties (ex: A low that looks like a mid).
Why is offline versus handicap removed?

[h3] I have been a fan of the franchise for over 10 years, all the way from T5:DR. There might be a few biased statements go unnoticed. Also, spoilers. [/h3]

[list]
[*] Story
The story tells the end of the longing Mishima father-son feud, and while it did a decent job of concluding it -- the execution from prior scenes are stale. You follow a vengeful journalist's research on the Mishimas, narrated throughout by his calming and disheartening voice. It feels like a visual novel, more than a fighting game. Akuma was apparently a significant part of the story, which doesn't make sense other than a crossover opportunity than lore. Not the worst, but it could be better.

[*] Gameplay
Tekken 7 has so many mechanics. This game is not for casuals, I can tell you that. With the addition of 2 more mechanics than its initial version, the gameplay could not be any more complex as of current. This game will take you days to getting used to, but once you've got the hang of it, you'll quite enjoy the overall gameplay. Characters have so much moves to memorize, it's intimidating. But variation begets opportunities, especially on combos. 

[*] File Size
The game has 80GBs. I recommend finding a file compressor for this problem.

[*] Graphics Compability
Unreal Engine games are usually demanding, so I'd recommend bench-marking your computer for this game. There's a mod somewhere that removes graphics in maps, so I'd recommend that downloading that too.
My computer specifications are: Intel i7 11th Gen (CPU) & Intel IrisXe Graphics (GPU), 16GB RAM. With the mods installed, I have a steady 57-60 fps rate. All graphics settings are set to low, with a 80% graphics resolution and 1600x900 screen resolution.

Here are some tips to try:
- Try not to search up any combo guides. Experiment and indulge in your own way, and you might find your own playstyle.

-  If you pressure yourself by saying, "Oh, it's not optimal -- this combo sucks!" - Stop it. The game will seem boring if you rely on optimal combos always, it's Tekken, darn it. Have some variety and have fun, even if its not optimal -- it may even open your mind for more things to explore.

I previously only had casual/limited experience playing fighting games but in July 2019 I bought Tekken 7 for PlayStation 4 on a whim and can honestly say that the decision to do so completely changed my life. I subsequently bought both the Xbox One and PC versions of the game just so I could play against as many different people as possible. I've put in well over 1,800 hours of gameplay across all three versions (1,350 of which are on Xbox) and have gone from being a total noob to reaching the online rank of True Tekken God (rank 35) with my main (Kuma) -- there are 37 ranks in Tekken 7, each one exponentially more difficult to achieve than the last as you must defeat opponents within two ranks of yourself to rank up, but losses to opponents within two ranks of yourself will cause you to rank down. Never before have I spent so much time outside of a game looking to improve my skills by reading strategies online and watching videos of professionals in an effort to become ranked as highly as I possibly can.

Tekken 7 gives back as much as you put in and even over 22,000 matches later there are still numerous techniques I'm yet to master and moves I'm yet to commit to memory with the character I main -- consider the fact that there are 50 characters on the roster and you have one hell of a deep fighting game. There is never a moment wasted whilst playing as you're always learning something new and honing your skills. The way the momentum can instantly shift due to a perfectly-timed counter hit or whiff punish makes each match so dynamic and exhilarating, and it means that epic comebacks are never out of the question.

However, that's not to suggest that the game is perfect. The load times are very lengthy (made more frustrating by the inability to instant rematch), the netcode is poor, the user interface is dull, the visuals are dated, there are very few modes, there is no proper tutorial, and rage quitters are common as there is minimal punishment for doing so. So, to put it another way, the game has clear flaws but none of them relate to the actual core gameplay which is truly sublime and as close to perfection as I've ever come across in a video game. 

Tekken 7 is an absolute masterpiece and has become, without question, my favourite competitive multiplayer game of all time. I'm 33 years old and have been a hardcore gamer all my life but no other game has even come close to the enjoyment, adrenaline, satisfaction, and sense of achievement that winning a single close-fought round in Tekken 7 can give me. If you're considering this game for its single-player then there are certainly better options out there, but when it comes to multiplayer fighting games then Tekken 7 simply has no equal.

Tekken 7 :

- No crossplays however. But we get crossplays in Tekken 8.

This game is fun casually but don't waste your time with anything more than that.

Edit : Climbed to higher ranks as a few characters (Kazuya, Lee, Jin, Lars) to find out for sure it doesn't get better. You get more points for winning than you lose for losing for the very large majority of ranks in the game so the skill level doesn't change much anyway. The shell of what is possibly my favorite game ever is in here somewhere but, in my opinion, the ability to have fun will almost never line up. 50+ characters and single digit "honest" characters who actually require learning a neutral game (no, your favorite way to mash into a flowchart doesn't count) or respecting your opponent. Overly evasive launchers on one button inputs, half health stealing knowledge checks that require hours of tedious homework to learn one matchup, or hand breaking movement techniques so that you can sit around and play whiff punish instead is the name of the game. Pick one and jump into ranked. Possibly forgivable, depending on your perspective and character choice, but that combined with this game's flaws almost everybody agrees on spoil the whole experience. Greedy DLC practices, terrible netcode, slow loading without good graphics to back it up, janky hitboxes, a complete lack of decent single player content, the ability to use "save states" for your rank on top of several exciting and classic ways to cheat, an antiquated lobby system, (subjectively) frustrating gameplay, a couple bangers but a very disappointing soundtrack compared to the old games, clear advantages for control schemes the game wasn't originally designed for, takes up half the space on your computer and takes hours to download so you'll never convince people to play it with you for more than a few sessions, and an objectively bad story (in this one, i like the old ones). You can't ask Bandai Namco "for shit" so maybe keep walking if they ask you for your hard earned cash on this one. Then again, this one sold so well that it regularly goes on sale for dirt cheap. Doesn't bode well for 8, but maybe worth a shot if the price is right. I wish I didn't agree 2300 hours ago.

Edit 2 : Good riddance.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

A Disappointing Fistful of Frustration"

TEKKEN 7, the latest installment in the renowned fighting game franchise, fails to live up to the high expectations set by its predecessors. Despite its impressive graphics and legacy, this game falls short on several fronts, leaving players more frustrated than entertained.

Uninspired Storyline:
One of the glaring weaknesses of TEKKEN 7 is its lackluster storyline. The narrative feels like a convoluted mess, attempting to tie up loose ends from previous games but ultimately failing to provide a compelling and coherent plot. Players may find themselves struggling to stay engaged, wondering if the convoluted story is even worth the effort.

Underwhelming Character Development:
While the game boasts a diverse roster of characters, the development of these fighters leaves much to be desired. Many characters lack depth, and the attempts at injecting personality often come across as forced or clich√©d. This lack of meaningful character development makes it challenging for players to form any real attachment to the fighters.

Questionable Balancing Issues:
TEKKEN 7 suffers from noticeable balancing problems, with certain characters dominating the playing field. This lack of balance undermines the competitive aspect of the game, leaving players frustrated when facing opponents who exploit these imbalances. The failure to address these issues through updates reflects a lack of commitment to creating a fair and enjoyable gaming experience.

Cumbersome Online Experience:
The online component of TEKKEN 7 is a source of considerable disappointment. Laggy matches, frequent disconnections, and a lack of dedicated servers contribute to a subpar online experience. This is a significant letdown for a game that heavily relies on its competitive multiplayer aspect.

Arcade Mode Repetition:
Arcade mode, a staple in fighting games, offers little variety in TEKKEN 7. The repetitive nature of battles and lack of innovation within this mode make it feel like a chore rather than an exciting part of the gameplay experience. The absence of meaningful rewards or incentives further diminishes the motivation to engage in this mode repeatedly.

In summary, TEKKEN 7 disappoints on multiple fronts, from its uninspired storyline and underdeveloped characters to balancing issues and a lackluster online experience. Fans of the franchise may find themselves longing for the days when TEKKEN was synonymous with cutting-edge fighting game excellence. Unfortunately, TEKKEN 7 fails to deliver the knockout punch it promised, leaving players grappling with disappointment rather than the thrill of victory.

Pros:
- Still a Tekken entry - good polish with slightly different timing of inputs and good follow-up mechanically.
- Local vs as well as unranked online with friends is working correctly.
- Accessible but challenging achievements (probably get a friend or two to make finding tournaments easier)

Cons:
- Nowhere near as rich in story as previous Tekken titles.
- Riddled with DLC microtransaction bloat, even in competitive.
- Online ranked matches suffer from a lot of lag. (No way to filter opponents by quality of connection)

I mostly play Tekken titles for the story, I have enough other multiplayer competitive stressful experiences. In that regard, this barely has any. The story takes ~5 hours to finish and is told from a rather boring perspective. Only one main storyline is fully finished with some one-off story beats accessible as well. The fights on normal difficulty would be challenging were it not for the typical weakness of nearly every fight being quick jab spam. Multiplayer is fun with friends, probably the only reason to get this title, any other kind suffers greatly from a lack of filtering options. Most ranked online matches are basically powerpoint presentations with 1-2 second input delay (Might've been a fluke? I haven't played much but I did try to play multiple different opponents and ~70% of unique match-ups ended up in what I described above) Tourneys are hard to come by with not much of a choice in terms of skill based matchmaking. This title might have at most been worth 20 bucks at release, with player pools saturated in different skill levels and with many more players with good connection. Now, this title would be worth about 5-10 bucks depending on how much you wanna play with friends.

I bought Tekken 7 just to play the story mode. It was short, but didn't disappoint, especially the final chapter.

Review just before Tekken 8 release: This is a bit of a wonky product in terms of playable content and quality, but there's undeniably a lot of fun to be had during matches. It can be argued that Tekken 7 "saved" the franchise. I'd recommend having it in your library especially when it goes on sale for 75+% off.

Locally, its best to be played with friends just mucking around or go to your nearest gaming/internet cafe and observe the community. Keep in mind those communities will (almost certainly) be embracing Tekken 8.

If you want to play solo then there's an incredibly deep wealth of fighting game knowledge to sink your teeth into and learn. There is a very high skill ceiling if you so wish to challenge yourself online and keep improving.

Having become obsessed with the Tekken franchise, I've made it my mission to play every Tekken game. So far I've played Tekken 1-4, Tekken Tag Tournament, T6, Tekken Tag Tournament 2, & now Tekken 7 and I must say this game kicks serious ass. You can tell they've really changed up the fighting style to still have a lot of the core Tekken traits, but also making it kind of Street Fighter-y because of a special someone newcomer Akuma from the Street Fighter franchise and it's honestly a nice change of pace. I used to have a problem with how I felt the block was a lot less effective than the previous installments but once you get into the groove of matches the fast-paced action really pays off in an amazing way. I have bought this game for so many people just because of how much I absolutely adore its easy to pick up and get into nature. My only real complaint is the fact some legacy characters are locked behind DLC and the definitive edition of the game unless on sale isn't really worth the price IMO. However I must say, Tekken 8 was even somehow more of a step up when I played the demo, really looking forward to it!

Tekken 7 will test your friendships, your relationships and just about everything else in your life.

That being said, it has some of the all time best characters, aesthetics and combat flow, as well as some of the absolute worst story modes in any game ever made. The narration and narrator in Tekken 7's story mode is by far the worst thing to ever happen in any form of interactive media and I fully recommend you play it at least once, for the few good parts, albeit muting all the inbetweens.

As a fighting game, Tekken 7 is absolutely great and entirely unfair. Anyone can play it, anyone can win and that makes it brilliant, but also very scary. I love the game, but it really can bring the worst out of yourself and your friends. It is a fun game to genuinely enjoy with people in the same room. Family, friends, the like. I highly recommend playing it like a party game. 3-4 people, taking turns in versus, is absolutely the best way to play the game. 2 people in a room with Tekken 7 means that the third player is the Devil. Nothing bad bad blood can occur.

Lucky Chloe was a character that many did not like, whereas she is my main and has brought me to the top of competitive play in arguably one of my strongest Tekken debuts of all time.

Earlier this year, some young people were playing it competitively at a convention hall. I asked them who was the best among them, as that is who I wanted to play. They assumed I was much older than I was and asked "What was the last one you played?" Like, what the hell, THIS one.

Either way, I was humbled but I came extremely close. The downside was that I was playing against a sweaty Law player with his own controller deck (these men shall never taste the humble glories of heaven and will know no salvation from the horrors of the material world), but it was great to make these guys get so hyped over seeing Lucky Chloe literally dance all over Law for a few rounds. In the end, Law meta cheese won but it was hard to be mad. Losing in Tekken is frustrating, yes, but it is a lot like having a fist fight in a busy highway and being mad a car hit you and killed you instantly. Some of the best Tekken victories are entirely accidental.

Now, the bowling.

Tekken bowling is one of the best things of this entire package. It can be utterly frustrating because it literally is, nothing but character meta and some characters simply should never have a bowling ball in their hands, let alone be allowed at a Bowling Alley in the first place.

But getting a Turkey, three strikes in a row, in this game is exhilarating. When you find a character who works well, when you understand who is best a power shooter and who is best at curve balling, this game ends up having a surprising amount of depth and honestly, Tekken bowling NEEDS its own standalone, like how Gwent from Witcher 3 did.

I promise you, Tekken Bowling is worth getting this older Tekken 7 for cheap, on the eve of Tekken 8. But only if you have IRL friends over frequently enough or family who enjoy what is the TRUE home-breaking party game.

For real though, the main story is absolutely horrible, besides like three set pieces and fights that are some of the best in the series. But everything else is truly amazing.

As a new Tekken 7 player, I genuinely enjoy the game while waiting for their newest installation. As many have mentioned, the online lag experience is the main thing that reduces the fun of the game. Hoping the next game will be different though.

Autism, formally called autism spectrum disorder (ASD) or autism spectrum condition (ASC),[6] is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by deficits in social communication and social interaction, and repetitive or restricted patterns of behaviors, interests, or activities, which can include hyper- and hypo-reactivity to sensory input. Autism is clinically regarded as a spectrum disorder, meaning that it can manifest very differently in each person. For example, some are nonverbal, while others have proficient spoken language. Because of this, there is wide variation in the support needs of people across the autism spectrum.

Very mixed opinions on Tekken 7, but i'll give it overall a positive.
It feels like everything good about this game has strings attached.

One good thing about Tekken is that it is a complex game. There's a lot of options both offensively and defensively. It allows for a great amount of player expression. and has a wide and varied enough roster to give a reasonably fun character for pretty much everybody.
If you like reading people's timings and playing aggressively, there's a character - if you like reading timings and playing defensively, there's a character for that, too. Same goes for pretty much every archetype. You don't have the issue you have in some games where you don't have any character that's quite you.

BUT..

While there are characters for everybody, that complexity comes right back to bite you in the ass. Learning even one character to a semi-playable level takes atleast an hour just to go through your movelist and learn some basic combos. When you have a roster of over 30 characters, no character descriptions whatsoever and no moveset organization, it makes it very hard to find the character that you actually enjoy. My favorite character is Bryan, but it took me over 100 hours (played on 2 accounts) to find him, and I'm still uncertain about him. 

The monetization of this game is pretty egregious - locking valuable frame data and labbing certain characters behind a paywall. While that data *can* be accessed online, it's much more inconvenient (especially if you have 1 monitor) and, at least for me, harder to internalize than if it is shown ingame.

Some of the highest IQ PvP experiences I have ever had come from this game. Some of the online matches I have played are comparable to something like 2000s elo or just straight up professional chess games. I'm talking something in the lines of Karpov vs. Kasparov, World Championship 1985, game 16, but even then, the fluidity and fortune teller's intuition that is displayed in Tekken is unparalleled. The Tekken community is also the most mysterious and weird community I have ever experienced. It is hard to tell if anyone you are matched against is truly a genius, a clairvoyant, or just a fool, as they can seem like all three at the same time.

This is Tekken - the best fighting game out there. There are other great and iconic fighting games like Street Fighter and Mortal Kombat, and while they have their own take on the genre, Tekken is the GOAT. Everything it does it just does better than its competitors - it's the ultimate fighting franchise. Only thing I can think to warn off players would be that it is also the most difficult to git gud at and it is the most complex of the major players in the genre.

Maybe you should wait for Tekken 8 to come out next year but if you want to play a fighting game now you can't go wrong with Tekken 7 and it will prepare you for 8. I would recommend looking at which characters are on the roster in 8 though so you don't choose to main a character in 7 who won't be there for 8.

It's crazy to think that for the longest time Tekken 5 was the "GOAT" of the franchise. I'd like to think that Tekken 7 did enough to take that title away. You can call this game a revitalization of the franchise after some really poor games following Tekken 5. 7 was the most fun I've had with a fighting game in a long time, and you can tell that this game was a pure labor of love. The amount of time and dedication the devs put into this game to make sure it was polished and well balanced clearly shows in the end product. Add in a fantastic returning cast with tons of interesting and unique DLC characters to boot and you got yourself an incredible fighting game. Noctis from FF15? NEEGAN from the Walking Dead? Never in my wildest imagination did I either think they'd be in a Tekken game. Well here we are. BRAVO TEKKEN BRAVO!

I'm by no means a competitive player or extreme beat-em-up enthusiast. However I fondly remember Tekken 3 in my teens on the original PSX. Not even the middle class commonly had any sort of practically usable "Internet". Our Wikipedia was some sad collection of CD's called "Microsoft Encarta/Enciclopedia". I would actually sit for countless hours practicing Tekken 3 combos from printed, expensive guide books in front of the cold glow of our analog CRT TV. Maybe I'm just too "oldschool", "rigid", melancholic or whatever... but already after briefly checking out one of the Tekken Tag-Tournaments in itself, AGES ago I noticed many combos/chains I still remember 25+ years later, the artstyle, fluidity and general vibe dramatically changed.

In the case of Tekken 3 I don't think it's mere nostalgia or "relative" amazement for a novel game in those olden days or experiencing things at such young age. The innovation, quality, vibe was simply superior. The artistic vibe and satisfaction from it's minimal b-mup story, actual oldschool CGI videos at the end of each Arcade-playthrough and even the soundtrack were all clearly made with incredible passion. Compare this to being greeted with a lazy "Game Over" after just 4-5 Arcade Mode opponents in this current installation and maybe you might somewhat believe second-hand that this talk might be about more than just romantic "nostalgia".

It might just be personal preference: but imho not much changed for the better - to be quite honest.
I was somehow hoping that maybe the series miraculously shifted somewhat back to it's origins after Tekken TT, 5 and 6? - I quickly checked out my main/favourite characters and their original combos/vibe; Lei, Jin, King etc. Only fractions appear to remain; And that's not even the very best bits.

"Kids" or newer gen might just react stereotypically "Aw just another rigid, old geezer, unable to 'adapt' git gud! l2p!"... but I think in some occasions old/original kinds of quality have their very own, maybe even very factual and objective merit and reason: Just listen to the super-nervous, cheezy/cheap and nauseating, extremely annoying soundtracks on many T7 occasions. What's going on? What happened?

I'll try to make a very basic example on Jin. One of my favourite/original combos with Jin in T3 was Square, Triangle, (faster) Cross, Circle. (slower) -> Two fast punches followed by Taekwondo'esque, scissoring top to bottom head-kicks or high-kicks. It used to be quite a simple/efficient and fast combo. But moreover it actually had a lot of style and physical "impact" in it's feel: it would truly come from the very top, hitting opponents on their head, collapsing their torsos downwards to be knocked back and up again. It would somewhat remind of the flexibility of Hwoarang's actual Taekwondo style, but it was still more linear, less swung and somewhat slower, i.e. more in Jin's cooler/powerful way. Very unique as all the moves, animations and vibes of all the characters.

Compared this basic example to T7; It's merely a 3-hit combo. And the remaining kick is replaced with extremely sloppy, inflexible front-kick without much of an organic or less so any sort of "martial arts" vibe to it. His (and many others') animations, fluidity and fighting style seem extremely rigid, sloppy... often comparable to some drunkard winding up for some meaningless brawl in a lousy bar.

On a sidenote and talking about uniqueness, details and quality: Jun, Jin's mother, being family actually had some rather cool "wheel" styled combos starting with simultaneous forward + Square + circle... to be continued with triangle, Square iirc. that were almost identical to Jin's "wheel" combo, as sort of a family thing, but even then each with their own twist and style. Pretty sure those combos (or even characters) no longer exist either, therefore that neat and very cool pattern and sort of family-vibe, is gone as well.

Obviously this just a basic, single example of great combos and things completely missing. I just watched a couple seconds of an old, pixelated  Hwoarang T3 video on YT and it takes less than 5-10 seconds to realize that something much more fluent, speedy and impressive is going on compared to what I witnessed, hoped for and still refunded today:

I might be very wrong but I somehow suspect a technical/artistic 3D gaming pipeline kind of issue. If you look at the textures in T3 with the graphics capabilities and techniques used in those days - they don't even seem like actual textures, but rather polygonal albedo-colors. Somewhat akin to the older Sega Virtua Fighter almost. "Lowpoly texture and model style". And I actually believe that, aside from inferior quality standards and modern greed might be a very core reason: I think in terms of flexibility with modern, more detailed standards or expectations in terms of 3D and textures specifically... the extremely fast and flexible moves from an old T3 would simply not even be possible with more modern standards, or at least the "realistic"/Fancy style and texturing used: Even if it's end result and extremely cheap and cheesy use for costumes/"style" is imho questionable, from and artistic and stylistic POV.

You see in 3D modelling, rigging, texturing and animation characters it's actually quite challenging, often impossible to move joints, limbs to extreme angles: as the detailed, high-quality textures would severely distort or even rip up the actual model. The texture, i.e. visual skin of the 3d model... has limitations.

I wouldn't be surprised if this technical difference between T3 and later releases had an actual impact on flexibility/angles and a way more impressive, impactful and fun implementation of characters, their combos movements and animations. For lower poly models with barely any textures that limitation should be much less of a problem.

What I wouldn't be surprised about either is if the olden T3 devs and publisher simply poured in more passion, time and money into their work... as well as actually consulting with martial arts pros and experts. As the movement and combat styles seem way more organic, dynamic, fluid and at least something that seems actually reminiscent of some sorts of martial arts.

What the devs should imho do is forget about many of the simply cheesy and awful cosmetics, costumes, DLC's and soundtrack and actually try some sort of modernized remaster, or better an entire, low-poly overhaul but based on Tekken 3 and in obvious high-res... obviously that wish or thought is somewhat ridiculous, but yea. It's what they should actually do, imho. And simply bash out the best modern fighting game to date. In T3's lowpoly heritage, but modernized style!

Tekken 3 was an absolute blast. And I don't mean to offend; But objectively, artistically and most importantly: from a gameplay, style, vibe and fun perspective - these new releases are merely a mediocre and pale shadow of what once was: I should grab my old PSX from the cellar or check on an emu and fire up T3. Maybe you should too - Especially if you never have... before. :) Even it's soundtrack is literally better than the entirety of this modern game.

I know this review will be greatly unneeded when TEKKEN 8 is finally released, yet I do believe I have to rewrite my opinions about it. I have to do this to appear more professional and also to warn the people who might get this game later on, as is the case with many people who go after older titles for nostalgia or to try what they had missed. And to those people I say...
[h1]IGNORE TEKKEN 7[/h1]


[h2]A truly great fighting game, a travesty compared to the past TEKKEN games[/h2]

This needs some explanation.
When it comes to battle mechanics and the gameplay, TEKKEN 7 appears extraordinary. The battle system is incredibly fun and the amount of customization it gives you, while not Soul Calibur levels of amazing, is pretty varied. However, the game has miserable amounts of in-game content due to its esports influences.

Ever since TEKKEN 3, the games of this series were loaded with tons of extra content; with Tekken Force, Tekken Ball, Tekken Bowl and Devil Within to name a few. But for some reason, which is what speculate to be more focus on esports, TEKKEN 7 has the most miserable amount of content in the history of the series and not only that, it downgrades the other modes it already has in favor of a disappointing story mode.

[h2]We really don't need a Mortal Kombat-esque story mode in all of our fighting games[/h2]

When Mortal Kombat 9 came out, everyone was mesmerized by its story mode and how well it narrated the story. That game managed to pull such a feat off with its vast amount of lore and the well-established history of the series. But it seems like everyone started to take wrong lessons from it. All of a sudden, everyone roared for story modes in fighting games and companies became desperate to put them in their games, no matter the cost. And this caused huge issues.

The thing is, not every game needs a story mode to be enjoyable. And adding a proper story mode to a fighting game, and one that never had such a mode, would take a lot of preparation. For example, TEKKEN and Street Fighter both have a story, but that story was told through arcade modes and opening/ending animations. SF6 did the transition well by the means of a custom character. And TEKKEN... well... it's not very good. Because not only the storyline feels uninteresting as a whole, but it also came at the cost of other modes of the game being lackluster.

[h2]How can a game released in ARCADES have such a miserable arcade mode?[/h2]

I don't know about you, but having 4-5 fights and then ending the whole thing without a cinematic or even a single picture, doesn't make for a good arcade mode. And don't get me started on the Character Episodes where the devs take the goofy, yet fun endings of the past TEKKEN games and turn it into pure cringe.

TEKKEN 7 has a big focus on appealing to the masses and online warriors and in doing so, has stopped being like what its predecessors were. Not only the arcade mode is heavily nerfed for a game that premiered on the arcades, none of the past modes return except for Treasure Battle and Tekken Bowl which the latter is locked behind a paywall. This means TEKKEN 7 is an online experience which is to the benefit of the publisher as they went on with tournaments, but doesn't help the casual audience; as they no longer have a simple way to pass time or train with the AI, will get demolished by experienced online players, and the game by itself will have no significant value when it's abandoned.


[h2]TL;DR[/h2]
TEKKEN 7 is a great fighting game, yet a miserable TEKKEN. It ditches & downgrades the series' iconic modes in favor of online and story modes, making for an inferior experience compared to past games.

Ok. This is going to be a long review, so bear with me.

I've played this game since it came out, I'm a pretty big fan of fighting games in general, and Tekken is the second series I attempted to be competitive in. I have 25+ years of Tekken experience, and 7 years trying to improve at being competitive.

The positives :
- Game mechanics : Rage Drive is a huge bonus to the Tekken formula. Rage Arts are cool but some get old quick.
- Impacts & hit effects are very satisfying in this game with shaky camera effects and great animations overall (despite some old Tekken 1-4 animations that would need to be updated)
- Easy to pick up & play but takes extremely long to master (due to the sheer amount of characters & moves)
- Pretty big roster (even without the DLCs), with a lot of different fighting styles
- Player matches are super fun, very easy to get into, and is a great way to find people to play with, and improve at the game.
- Probably the best roster in the whole series, and it still stands as one of the most balanced fighting games there is (although certain DLC characters) do have some advantages.

The negatives :
- The 3d models & graphics are subpar, even for the time it came out (Feb 18, 2015 in Arcades)
- Way too many characters with all the DLCs for a one on one fighting game (to me, less is more).
- Learning to counter every character in the roster is extremely tedious.
- Online has extremely bad issues (rank savers, cheaters, desyncs and crashes mid game). They added a few frames of rollback in the 4th season but when there are cheaters around ? I don't think it matters.
- Ranked match mode is pretty much done after red ranks at this time.
- Single player content is the worst in the whole series in my opinion. Practice, Arcade, a quite boring Story mode (both the main story & the character endings which are abysmal), & maybe some snooze fest of a Tekken Bowl mode DLC that gives you a title & hit effects ? Not worth the time.

In conclusion, the excellent gameplay of Tekken 7 saves it, despite the lackluster single player modes and the
aging graphics. The animations, the new Rage mechanics, the great guest characters easily make up for this when playing online, or in Versus mode with a bunch of friends. All in all, fun times indeed.

Notes : 
*This game can be extremely frustrating if you don't know what you're losing to, and there's so much stuff to learn that it takes years to learn it (I'm still getting blown up by both Nina & Noctis players haha).
*Best advice for starting out in the game is to go to ranked match at first (mashing some buttons is always fun in Tekken) and after you get some experience and reach red ranks, you can start doing player matches.

[b]Imagine a high-tech fighting arena where every fighter has their own story and skill set. It's like a superhero showdown, but instead of capes, they've got killer moves.

The game's mechanics are smooth as butter ‚Äì it's like playing with a finely-tuned machine. Each button press is like a line of code, triggering combos and attacks that feel as satisfying as cracking a tough gaming level.

Tekken 7 isn't just about button-mashing; it's about strategy and timing. It's like a chess match with fists. You've got to think on your feet, predict your opponent's moves, and land that killer blow.

The graphics and animations are like something out of a sci-fi movie. Every character looks sharp, moves fluidly, and unleashes their own special brand of havoc.

Whether you're a casual gamer or a hardcore enthusiast, Tekken 7 offers a thrilling and adrenaline-pumping experience. It's not just a game; it's a martial arts masterpiece waiting for you to become the ultimate champion."

Hope this review captures the essence of Tekken 7 for you![/b]

Okay so I finally (hopefully) understood TEKKEN and what it's suppose to be as a game.
TEKKEN 7 is often perceived as this intimidating super-competitive and stressful game that requires razor-sharp focus with no flaws or balancing mistakes. However, this is not entirely true. Like any other game, TEKKEN 7 has its flaws and features. The primary objective is to have fun, and you can start by selecting a main character that suits you and practicing with them.
DON'T PLAY TEKKEN TOO EMOTIONALLY to the point of not having fun because you will ruin your experience and mental health.
The whole point is to have fun and that's it. 
First you choose a main, someone who fits you personally and you like or think looks cool since practicing with your favorite character is a great way to stay motivated and make some progress. Discovering cool new things about your character that you can do, keeps it fresh along the way and helps you improve in the long run. Don't be afraid to change that character anytime you want.
However, sometimes the game can be frustrating when faced with unfair or overly punishing characters or moves. In those cases, it's essential to take a break and cool off since the whole point is to have fun.
With time and practice, you'll begin to notice the flaws in characters you previously thought were unbeatable. You'll learn new ways to counter their moves and playstyle, eventually beating them. This can be an incredibly satisfying experience that helps build up your confidence. You feel the rush, you feel like you're more capable now. The top tier pros that looked impossible to comprehend, now start to look more human. You get a feel for the game. Your first response to seeing something "op" or "unfair" is to find a way to counter it and style on the person using them. It's important to have a positive attitude and not to insult people or spam cheap moves. Remember, the objective is to have fun, not to win at all costs all the time. The game has its flaws, such as long loading times and an annoying soundtrack. However, you can always turn down the volume or play your music if that helps.
End note: Just have fun bastards >:(

Tekken 7 is the latest (not anymore but you get the point) iteration of the Tekken franchise. This game has vastly superior graphics, mechanics in the form of chains and juggles, and a decent story line. I can wholeheartedly say that this is one of the most, if not the most complex fighting game. 
All the combo mechanics flow like clockwork, and have a satisfying blow on each hit or punish. Both the community and mainstream support is growing far more than the days of old, hell, even the development of season 3 years after the original release is due to the tournament popularity. You'll find hundreds of guides and/or weird customization mods all over the place. However, in my opinion the biggest detriment to this game is its huge paywall. Even legacy characters (which were promised to be free) are [b]paid[/b] DLC.
[h1]Pros: [/h1] [list]
[*]Versatile cast of characters with very unique movesets
[*]Good enough story (with a summary of all past Tekken games included to help you understand it)
[*]Good optimization for a PC port
[*]Easy to learn/ Really hard to master
[*]Variety in stages and soundtrack
[*]Loads of wonky customization items and even wonkier mods [i](I'm looking at you, school girl Heihachi)[/i] [/list]

[h1]Cons: [/h1] [list]
[*]Some characters' hitboxes seem out of sync at times
[*]A high paywall to unlock the complete game
[*]git gud [/list]

[h1][b]Tekken 7: A Fighting Game Masterpiece that Packs a Punch[/b][/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Diverse Roster: Tekken 7 boasts an unparalleled roster of diverse characters, each with their own unique fighting style and backstory. From classic favorites to new additions, the roster caters to a wide range of playstyles, ensuring there's a character for every player.[/b]

[*][b]Fluid Gameplay: The gameplay mechanics in Tekken 7 are smooth, responsive, and deeply satisfying. Every punch, kick, and combo feels impactful, and the game rewards skillful execution. The depth of the combat system allows for strategic and competitive play, making each match a thrilling experience.[/b]

[*][b]Stunning Visuals: The game's visuals are a visual feast, with detailed character models, vibrant stages, and eye-catching special effects. The attention to detail is impressive, bringing each fighter to life and immersing players in a visually captivating world.[/b]

[*][b]Engaging Story: Tekken 7's story mode offers an engaging narrative that dives into the rich history of the Mishima clan. It delves into personal rivalries, family conflicts, and the consequences of past actions. The story mode adds depth and context to the battles, enhancing the overall experience.[/b]

[*][b]Thriving Competitive Scene: With a dedicated community and a thriving competitive scene, Tekken 7 offers endless opportunities for players to test their skills. From local tournaments to global championships, the game's competitive scene is alive and vibrant, providing an avenue for players to showcase their mastery.[/b]
[/list]
[b][i]Tekken 7 stands as a fighting game masterpiece, delivering diverse characters, fluid gameplay, stunning visuals, an engaging story, and a thriving competitive scene. Whether you're a casual player seeking thrilling battles or a competitive gamer aiming for victory, Tekken 7 offers an exhilarating and unforgettable fighting game experience.[/i][/b]

[b]As someone who occasionally steps into the realm of fighting games, delving into Tekken 7 was a unique experience that transcended my limited exposure to this genre. This game, a staple in the fighting game community, offered a captivating journey that intrigued me far beyond my usual gaming repertoire.[/b]
[list]
[*]The first thing that struck me was the sheer visual brilliance. The character animations, detailed environments, and vibrant colors painted a mesmerizing picture, akin to watching an intricately choreographed martial arts film. Despite my limited expertise in fighting games, I found myself captivated by the stunning visual spectacle this game presented.

[*]Beyond its visual allure, Tekken 7's accessibility surprised me. As someone who doesn't often delve into complex fighting mechanics, the game's initial simplicity allowed for an easy entry. However, beneath this simplicity lies a depth that I only began to scratch the surface of during my playtime. The strategic depth of timing, combos, and character selection became apparent as I delved deeper.

[*]The character roster was another intriguing aspect. Each character felt unique, with their own storyline, moveset, and depth that added a layer of complexity and made me want to explore more. Whether I was trying out the iconic Mishima family members or the newer additions, each character felt like a journey into a different fighting style.

[*]Tekken 7's storyline, although entangled in the Mishima family saga, managed to keep me engaged despite my limited familiarity with the series. The cinematic story mode felt like stepping into an immersive narrative, even though I didn't grasp all the nuances of the lore.

[*]While my exposure to online battles was brief, the competitive spirit of the game was palpable. I could sense the thrill and challenge of facing opponents worldwide, which I imagine would offer immense satisfaction to those who invest time mastering its mechanics.
[/list]
[b]In conclusion, Tekken 7 surprised me with its visual prowess, accessibility, and depth, offering a glimpse into the captivating world of fighting games. For someone like me, a casual player in this genre, it was a journey that broadened my gaming horizons and left me impressed with its intricacies. Whether you're a fighting game enthusiast or a novice like me, Tekken 7's allure is undeniable and worth exploring.[/b]

For me It's the best fighting game that ever made.
It's like a chess game, you really have to learn all basic moves, combos, punishments and defends to play this game. Because when you have decided to play the game in online mode, you'll need more stamina on your body to be prepared, it won't only make you tired by hitting buttons on your stick or d-pad, but also need to be more concentrate and use your brain before deciding to attack your opponent. One wrong step you made, then your opponent will break you down and demote your rank.
Yes, it's a little bit frustrating but also make you addicted to keep playing and trying. The graphics, the background music, and everything in this game it's almost perfect to all fighting gamers.

If rank match makes you tired, you can try other modes like treasure battle or even story mode. Treasure battle is really really fun, some other battle types such as turbo battle, double damage battle, etc. that you can't play those battle types in normal battle will make you feel relieved.
Also the story mode, I believe some of you guys will love the character of Heihachi. He taught me that as a man, we really need to have soft heart, but also hard skin. Just check it guys, I won't spoil it why Heihachi has a really father material here.

And to be fair, I really need to give my opinion to Bandai Namco about Tekken 7 save methods, I think it'll be better if rank data is saved on cloud saver than local folder. A week ago I got those bad moments when my PC shut down while playing Tekken 7, and unfortunately all my data was corrupted. I haven't backed up all my data yet, so I needed to restart everything, even my rank started on Beginner again. I hope this problem will get the best solution on next update or may be next Tekken series. So guys, if you wanna buy this game, don't forget to always back up your data every time you have done playing the game. You can always back up your saves data here:
C:\Users\User\AppData\Local\TekkenGame\Saved

A quality release from Bamco. Overall a solid fighting game with good netcode. That being said there's a lot more to be improved.

Single player content, it's lacking. I'm disappointed Tekken Force doesn't make it because they are focusing on story mode and improving the fighting system from what I heard. Then again I appreciate they re-imagining T4 Honmaru battle. Watching T5 intro was epic enough, experiencing the battle itself? That was incredibly fun! For treasure battle, while it's fun getting loot, it doesn't feel as fun as ghost battle in T6. I want to change it to 3 rounds-to-win with very hard diff but apparently game setting doesn't affect it. I don't know, 2 rounds game feels too short. Arcade mode is useless and hopefully the new game mode gives some replayability.

Customization, a wasted potential. With plethora of items (and t-shirts) it doesn't have some common items. I want to customize Jin with black business suit so I can look dapper when kicking butts but nope. Shaheen has it but it seems exclusive to him? We could have uniques but for common stuff like this it shouldn't be. And they could really add extra hair styles like seriously. They are probably aiming for DLC but yeah I guess I have to wait. EDIT: Missing costume set like Asuka Dojo outfit. it's unique and defines her as the Kazama-style practicioner.


Character specific story, it's embarrassing. They could've just do it like traditional arcade mode, a set of match with some cutscenes here and there and I'll be fine with it. Instead we only have a SINGLE match. Getting ending story after trashing Jinpachi or tryharding Azazel feels way more satisfying even all I get is cheesy ending because at least I put some effort into it.

Tutorial mode. While practice mode is fleshed out, it's raw. Newbie players usually like this: Play online > get rekt > take refuge in Practice Mode > test combos against unmoving target practice or spar with overly aggressive AI > come up online again > still get rekt > quit. Tutorial mode is great for basic fundamentals like getting up from the ground, spacing, etc. It helps to make new people get better and results more players online. EDIT: [b]Record my own combo.[/b] Mortal Kombat X had it and it useful to showcase combos. [b]Option to pick last round music/stage in Practice Mode.[/b] Some of those music are really good and I want to practice in Devil's Pit infinite stage because Azure is getting boring.

Online mode
-Recent player list so if you fought with good players you can add them to practice with you.
-Replay feature. I'd like to watch my losing match so I could figure out what needs to be improved or just want to show off that one close match. Street Fighter V which also use Unreal Engine 4 has this feature so no reason for Tekken 7 to exclude this one.
-An interface that show your friends that also playing so you can invite them to 1v1 or tournament.
-EDIT: This doesn't apply only to online mode but option to remember side fight (Left/Right/Always Ask/Random). 

Gallery
While I appreciate the extensive artwork/movie gallery, there is no Tekken Music Player. Tekken 7 features double music every stage resulting in more awesome music from Namco Sound Team and yet there is no player for that. I get that we're on PC so you might suggest just turn on Youtube? Yeah, we shouldn't need 3rd party for that. But then again, I really appreciate for putting artwork from every Tekken series. I can't believe Tekken game is 20 years old and counting!

TL;DR Tekken 7 is a must-play for fighting game fans. There won't be new Tekken for at least next 5 years so play this one!

[b]Hey there, fellow gamers! Get ready to throw down and experience Tekken 7, a game that's the epitome of martial arts finesse and adrenaline-fueled showdowns. Let's break it down:[/b]
[list]
[*][i]Fist-Flying Action: Tekken 7 is like a dojo of champions, where every punch, kick, and combo feels like a martial arts symphony. It's not just fighting; it's an art form.[/i]

[*][i]Visual Brilliance: The game's visuals are on another level. It's like witnessing a martial arts movie come to life, with vibrant characters and stunningly detailed environments that breathe life into the fights.[/i]

[*][i]Strategic Combat: Beyond flashy moves, Tekken 7 requires strategic finesse. It's like a game of mental chess, where timing, combos, and mastering your favorite fighter's moves are the keys to victory.[/i]

[*][i]Legendary Characters: The character roster is a powerhouse of diverse fighters. From classic icons to newcomers, each fighter has a unique story and fighting style. It's like assembling a squad of martial arts legends.[/i]

[*][i]Thrilling Story Mode: The game's story mode is like a gripping martial arts saga. Dive into the Mishima family feud and experience the emotional rollercoaster of the characters. It's not just fighting; it's a dramatic journey.[/i]

[*][i]Online Showdowns: Take the battle global! The online battles are intense, challenging, and oh-so-satisfying. It's like testing your skills against fighters from around the world.[/i]

[*][i]Customization and Unlocks: Unlockables and customization options add depth. It's like personalizing your fighter's appearance and abilities, making them a reflection of your martial arts prowess.[/i]

[*][i]Competitive Scene: Beyond casual play, Tekken 7 has a thriving competitive scene. It's like entering a world of esports where the best fighters face off in legendary matches.[/i]
[/list]
[b]In summary, Tekken 7 isn't just a fighting game; it's a martial arts spectacle that demands skill, strategy, and dedication. Whether you're a seasoned fighter or new to the dojo, this game offers an immersive experience that's bound to keep you hooked. So, grab your controller, select your fighter, and step into the ring for an epic brawl you won't forget![/b]

[b]Alright, fellow gamers, let's step into the ring with Tekken 7, a game that's throwing the meanest punches and standing tall as the reigning champ of fighting games. Here's why this game's got that knockout punch:[/b]
[list]
[*][b]Iconic Battles: Tekken 7 is a very good game... best fighting game out there! The fights are like electrifying dance-offs, where each character brings their unique style and moves to the forefront.[/b]

[*][b]Visually Stunning: The game's graphics are on point, capturing every punch, kick, and slam in jaw-dropping detail. It's like watching a martial arts movie come to life in your gaming console.[/b]

[*][b]Deep Combat System: The combat mechanics are where Tekken 7 shines. It's not just about button-mashing; it's about timing, strategy, and mastering combos. It's like a chess match, but with fists and kicks.[/b]

[*][b]Roster Diversity: The character roster is diverse and packed with personality. From classic fighters to newcomers, each has their own story and fighting style. It's like assembling a dream team of martial artists.[/b]

[*][b]Storyline Intensity: The game's story mode dives deep into the Mishima family saga. It's like being in the middle of a dramatic martial arts epic, with twists and turns that'll keep you hooked.[/b]

[*][b]Online Showdowns: Online battles take the challenge to a whole new level. Testing your skills against other players worldwide feels exhilarating and brings out the competitive spirit.[/b]

[*][b]Customization and Unlockables: The game offers tons of unlockables and customization options. It's like crafting your fighter's appearance and style, making them truly your own.[/b]
[/list]
[b]In summary, Tekken 7 is a powerhouse of a fighting game that's not just about brawls; it's an artful display of skill, strategy, and character depth. Whether you're a fighting game aficionado or new to the genre, this game's a must-play. So grab your controller, choose your fighter, and step into the ring for a fighting experience that's second to none![/b]

Ah, TEKKEN, probably one of my all time favorite game franchises. Heck, its my defacto favorite fighting game series. And TEKKEN 7 is the series' best offering yet. 

[b]PROS[/b]
[list]
    [*]Wide characters with even wider movelists
    [*]Treasure Battle is loads of fun
    [*]Character Customization is decent
    [*]The 8 second lag present in console versions DOES NOT EXIST ON PC
    [*]Decent netcode and online presence - except torunament mode, you can easily find match on other online modes
    [*]Helpful community - places such as r/tekken and tekken federation are eager to help you
[/list]

[b]CONS[/b]
[list]
    [*]Siginificantly fewer characters than the last entry (TAG 2). Though this was done to prevent newcomers from alegedly feeling overwhelmed
    [*]Customization lacking, though there is a promise of future free dlc adding characters and customization items
    [*]Game is difficult later on in ranked matches if you refuse to learn how to [strike]git gud[/strike] play decently
    [*]Story mode is underwhelming, and doesn't actually end the Mishima saga
    [*]DLC so far has been lack lusture and apart from Eliza, not worth your moolah
    [*]Some may argue that Rage Drives and Rage Arts (basically finisher moves) do not belong in a more realistic fighter such as TEKKEN (though i disagree, it adds great challenge and blocking them us fun)
[/list]

TL;DR

I really love Tekken, the world of Tekken is funny and badass at the same time. You have a man who has a jimmy neutron haircut and everyone takes him seriously, we havea wrestler who only communicates in growls, and the characters are the obvious standouts of the game as well as their designs. The designs for many of the characters have that magical design and personality to them that it is shame some of them are not gonna be in the base roster of the next game. Fighting itself is challenging and it really does feel like you need to learn the character thoroughly in order to succeed. What sucks about this game is the online community, I feel like this applies to any multiplayer game but I feel like most people who you find in Tekken online are complete assholes and egotistical. I just wish that there would be some sort of way to differentiate problem people in this game so that I dont have to fight with some weirdo who ki charges and tea bags. The soundtrack is electric and while some songs do blare and just become noise at some point, heat haze shadow nullifies any complaint with the soundtrack. Tekken is all bout proving yourself to be skilful enough to overcome the mechanics of the game while mastering characters as if you are mastering their own fighting style. Tekken is funny, electric, and has stoked a fiery passion within me. I love Tekken 7.

First of all, Thumbs down does not apply to everyone. Since there's no middle-ground indicator, I just went with it due to overall impression

Pros:
Great core game mechanic
Gorgeous graphic
Unique characters with their own fighting styles. Even Mishimas have different tempo despite both having hellsweep and EWGF

Cons: 
Paid frame data display
Emphasis on close-quarter brawling means every match is solely MU quiz instead of being creative with supposed game mechanic like movements, which seems less effective in 7 compared to previous iteration of Tekken
Comeback mechanics like Rage Art and Rage Drive changes game dynamic way too much
Mostly boring and terrible OST
Mostly boring stages
Huge lack of single play experience
Story mode is laughably bad
Individual character stories are disjointed or complete joke
Unstable online experience


Overall: If you've been playing Tekken franchise for so long or beginner that intends to spend 10 years of your life dedicated to nothing but Tekken, then this game is definitely recommended. For casuals or people with very little time to commit towards training and learning MU painstakingly, this is not for you.

5 /10 . I wish I could give a "mixed" or "recommend on sale" verdict. This was a little disappointing for me. I tried to like Tekken 7 because I really like Tekken 5 and 6. 

+Looks amazing. Stages, lighting, and new story cut-scenes look especially good graphically. 

+/-  The DLC characters are interesting, but y'know, ...

-Most of the new non-dlc characters are really uninteresting both in being move-set-clones and story lore wise. 

-Speaking of which, the story is really short this time too and the fights are full of cheesing there (probably to hide the cheesing already present in the normal mechanics...), but at least there are some seriously epic moments even if it is rich with spams

-The new rage art system kinda overwhelms some of the truthfully good base mechanics improvement especially with easily spammed special moves and huge dmg buffs that make fights feeling far too short and less like the long epic battles I used to have. 

-A lot of this game's download time is due to being crammed with re-releases of nearly every cut-scene from nearly every previous Tekken game. YouTube exists, so this seems like game filler to me. 

 -There's so many iconic characters missing at launch. I mean, how do you have Law but not Lei or worse yet Nina but without Anna?? They complete each other and classics should stop being behind DLC paywalls. It's frankly a bit elitist aside from being obviously greedy. 
  
     **Where is Baek or his clone character!?  I'm a Baek main out in the cold here.  Baek has been in Tekken since Tekken 2. C'mon!


-No interesting side modes.  Seriously and straight-faced tell me you like Tekken for the bowling. Smh. 

-Customization is a huge joke with very little variety being mostly, well, just a lot of joke accessory garbage and not enough to make some look-alike or highly-detailed character like you can in Bamco's Soul Calibur games. 

-The season passes are a bit over-priced for what you actually get. 

-Even the soundtrack is uninspired this time with some seriously tedious dubstep loops.


tl;dr :  not a "terrible game" necessarily, and sometimes down right badass even in the visuals, but as a Tekken sequel (and let's be real, fighting game sequels theses days are more like updates) and for a game so pro-esports and mainstream, it's terribly unbalanced and over-hyped

As a long-term Tekken fan, I've really enjoyed Tekken 7 over the years. Although I didn't enjoy season 1 too much, since then it has delivered with new stages, characters and even given us frame data, something I never thought we'd get. I can play Tekken for hours and never really get bored since the online features provide lots of replay value.

My only two complaints are:
- The offline content could be better, like Tekken 6's scenario campaign. 
- The loading times are insanely long, even if you're quick matching/rematching someone in a lobby.

Overall, Tekken 7 is a solid addition to the Tekken series and whilst it is a difficult game to pick up, once you learn the mechanics, it is so enjoyable.

After playing it for a while you realize that it is full of errors. Erratic hit priority in slow motion sequences, terrible network performance in multiplayer, completely inconsistent ranking for assigning contenders in games (as it is possible for a 1st dan with 0V to be assigned another 1st dan with more than 100 victories ?). A marked key input delay and very limited movement with weapons. On the other hand, the system does not punish spam players (they are a nuisance), it only penalizes disconnection. Finally the allocation of points in multiplayer fights is crazy, you rise too slowly and fall too quickly. I really hope that version 8 significantly improves on the above.

Wait for Tekken 8. This game is garbage

PC port sucks, will crash on alt-tab consistently. Frame drops on either side lead to bad lag spikes during online matches.

Online is bad: long queue times, filters often ignored, bad connections, no hardware display for the opponent. Also de-syncs are pretty common where the match will have to be cancelled after a few minutes.

Generally overpowered DLC: this speaks for itself at this point. Balance is pretty poor in general.

All fundamental aspects of Tekken are worse than in past entries. High combo damage, low punishment damage, bloated movelists, and bad movement. The game is very scrubby at most levels of play due to this.

Customization is somehow significantly worse than Tag 2, the previous entry. Outfits and clothing pieces don't fit the character properly, and often clip through the model or the character or other clothing pieces.

Paid frame data. Lol.


If you want a decent Tekken experience, emulate a past entry like Tag 2 or Tekken 6, or wait for Tekken 8, which will hopefully be good, but given the Tekken Team's decision making skills I don't count on it.

TEKKEN 7 adalah petarung 3D yang membuat pemain terhibur melalui intinya "latihan menjadi sempurna," karena ada banyak hal yang harus dipelajari dan dikuasai di kedalaman judul ini. Panggung dan musiknya menyatu dengan indah di layar, menambah ketegangan dan emosi pada setiap pertandingan. Dipasangkan dengan hubungan dinamis antara aksi cepat dengan tempo lambat, ini menciptakan lingkungan di mana pertarungan berlangsung dengan penuh semangat, dan setiap ronde sangat berarti.

TEKKEN 7 adalah gim yang fantastis jika Anda mencari gim pertarungan dengan banyak kedalaman dan tidak keberatan untuk belajar dan melatih keahlian Anda untuk menyempurnakannya. Game ini lebih menuntut daripada game sejenisnya dalam hal dedikasi yang harus dicurahkan. Namun, dengan banyak konten di game dasarnya ditambah DLC dan online yang solid, ini adalah pembelian yang bagus untuk siapa saja yang tertarik dan untuk penggemar game pertarungan. Jika Anda ingin masuk ke genre ini untuk pertama kalinya, pertimbangkan opsi lain atau lakukan dengan penuh kesabaran. Gim yang hebat secara keseluruhan, dengan banyak hal yang terjadi meskipun ada beberapa keputusan yang gagal; Saya bersenang-senang dengan TEKKEN 7!

Tekken is a all time favorite and a classic.

Fantastic and very deep fighting game. At this late point of its development, it has dozens of cool characters and stages. The graphics are solid Unreal Engie, but not nearly as good as in SF6. The art design is dark anime. In terms of gameplay, the game is phenomenal - enjoyable at every level and infinitely deep. There is a campaign that is basically a decent anime movie. And, of course, you can fight online.

I know Tekken 8 is coming out soon; but this one goes for just ~$15 on sales, and is worth it if you feel like a nice fighter game. A classic.

Love the game.
First fighting game I ever played that has over 20 characters.
Beside the large amount of storage it takes up, it's over all a really good game.

The fact that's it's a 3D (not 2D) fighting game gives it a lot of depth. you are able to move around the battlefield in a few small but very significant ways as well as each character having 100+ combos that have to be performed by pressing the four main buttons and the four move buttons in sequence. Each of the four hit buttons are tied to each of the characters limbs, so that's easy to understand. The graphics, characters and story are also a good improvement from previous entries in the series. It works with a variety of controllers especially the keyboard.
The only problems I have with the game is the huge storage and your PC needs to be able to handle the game especially online

Can recommend it but only under certain circumstances.
1. Story Mode is enough for you as an Offline content. Though story is somewhat boring it is better to just skip to fights.
2. You are a veteran.
3. You are okay with paid Frame Data,DLC Characters(lot of which appeared in previous title).
4. You are willing to spend a lot of time in practice mode to lab characters if you want to win due to too many moves or strings to remember, some mids looking like lows,some lows looking like mids and some highs looking like mids etc. 500hrs(including AFK,430 with ingame timer) you see here is nothing,if this is your first proper Tekken or FG in general,like is the case for me.

Anyways as of now, there are not a lot of players online so chances are you would be pitted against same players over and over again. So where's the variety of fighting different people? Waiting time more than 3 minutes if you set connection to be +3 bar, lots of smurfs or veterans or alternate characters on low ranks. Though latter could be fixed if you were ranked up globally. Edit: Also expect lag switchers,overlay,auto blockers,auto punish,speed boost and outside macro users in ranked mode. And there being no ingame tool to blacklist such players from being matched(if the game can use ML algorithm to detect those with high efficiency,it should give us an option to blacklist them,else don't because it can be abused to duck matches otherwise, or save replay with similar lag levels so that it can be reported to devs later but none of that).

If you are a new player at this point of time you might get beat a lot since you might be playing with experienced players.  

Then if you search up for Tournaments,it is empty most of the times and when searching for lobby matches expect players who create public lobbies who kick you for no reason as if private lobbies aren't a thing. Toxicity also exceeds to where someone will trash talk you after you win or lose when they play some execution heavy characters.

Offline doesn't have much content apart from arcade(which has very few fights),story mode and treasure battle, customization seems to be lacking compared to previous titles.
