‚ô° I'm a big fan of Tekken and I play Tekken 7 quite often. I really enjoy the ability to customize characters and the return of some of the previous game's characters. While some characters require purchasing, there are plenty of characters to start with, so it's not a major issue. The graphics are stunning and the combos are impressive. 

‚ô° The graphics, maps, and music of this slightly older game are impressive. However, it requires a considerable amount of computer power, so it's advisable to have a decent computer or to play it on a console that can handle it. If you want to play with friends, you can use remote play, or play online or alone locally. The game offers great options, and the storyline is also interesting.

‚ô° The character selection for customization is excellent, and I've always been impressed by Tekken games. However, the price is a bit high, so I recommend waiting for a sale, especially since a new version is coming out. The only downside I've noticed is the inclusion of Rage Arts, but it seems to be a common feature in newer fighting games.

I'm what you'd consider a semi-late arrival to the franchise. My first experience was Tekken 6 on PSP when I was still little and I loved it just for the variety of characters as well as for it's atmosphere. I was unable to figure out the inputs for the harder moves and throws, but I still loved it and to be honest it was my only exposure to fighting games till teenage years anyway. I also got to experience Tekken 5 on PSP as well as my friend gifted if to me, those were really fun times. 

Now in my late teens after having tried multiple 2D fighting games like Guilty Gear and Skullgirls and whatnot I once again set my eyes on Tekken. I was mildly aware of there being a sequel, but I couldn't have possibly imagined it had a full-blown huge multiplayer scene now as well as a continuation to the awesome glimpse of a story I witnessed in TK5 and 6. 

After like 400 hours I can definitely say that this is the fighting game that I have sunk the most hours of my life into and although I still suck and it can sometimes make me rage I still love it as that same bizarre fighting game with bears, space samurais and weird-hair guys from my childhood. TK7 is much more fleshed out than it's predecessors in gameplay sense and although it puts much less focus to individual characters' stories which makes me sad - it still mostly maintains it's identity and I'm very excited to see what Tekken 8 brings. I can definitely call myself a Tekken fan now.

Fuelled by nostalgic memories of Tekken: Tag Tournament, Tekken 5 and Tekken 6, I bought this game on sale recently to scratch a long-standing itch to learn a fighting game and to see what became of this staple from years ago. One broken controller and 34 hours later and I'm well-versed in the hieroglyphics-like language of Tekken jargon and combos, tens of wins in and I'm addicted to the game with a feeling  of accomplishment and steady improvement. 

The single-player is barely existent and this now 8 year old game is due to be replaced by is sequel in January but the online is still very populated and learning resources are plentiful. Great music, perfect gameplay, decent net code and well-aged graphics amount to what is my current favourite fighting game, even as other series have already upgraded.

The learning curve is more of a learning spike, losing can be infuriating and disheartening, wins sometimes feel more fluke than skill and you will learn to hate seeing certain characters and moves but persevere and I guarantee you will learn to love this unforgiving beast.
I dont recommend purely down to how much it will cost you to get everything, keeping in mind how close T8 is at the time of the review

This game is just perfect if you can just ignore the

- Bad netcode which makes it impossible to play with WiFi players.
- Locally stored ranks filling lobbies with smurfs or rank cheaters.
- Worst offline experience.
- Frame data DLC.
- Impossible task of labbing DLC characters without buying them.
- Non existent tutorial mode.
- Ki Charging Toxic win quitters.
- Incompetent players who DM just to be toxic.
- Broken and braindead top tiers who are still untouched.
- Commodore 64 levels of loading times, even for rematches!
- Tournament mode and lobbies that barely functions.

Apart from these few minor oversights, it is still a great dressing simulator with a fighting game on the side. Would recommend 10/10!

As an 80-year-old gamer who has been playing video games since the days of Pong and Space Invaders, I've seen the gaming world evolve and transform. Tekken 7, the latest iteration of the renowned Tekken series, holds a special place in my heart as it combines the nostalgia of classic arcade fighters with the cutting-edge technology of today's gaming consoles. In this review, I will share my perspective on how Tekken 7 caters to both veterans like myself and the younger generation of gamers.
Tekken 7 is a fantastic despite it's age and still holds up well compared to modern fighter games.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

A fairly good fighting game on its own, yet plagued with issues including the ridiculously expensive DLC for things as simple as frame data.

400 hours in the game total across main and smurf accounts, gaming lounges and local gaming events (tourney and non-tourney). Intermediate Level as well (Emperor to Tekken God Omega level). Played competitively since 2019 and returned to the game in 2021 after I finally got a PC of my own. Characters I play are Lars, Dragunov and Kazumi

This game is not Tekken nor is it even a 3D Fighting game, its a 2.5D game and its barely that. Anyways, lets get to the reasons as to why this game sucks:

- Extreme balancing issues (particularly since Season 3)
- Hoards of incredibly frustrating and noob friendly mechanics (Rage Art, Rage Drive, Power Crush etc.)
- Movement being terrible (already explained above prior to listing my cons with this stupidly retarded ungodly game) 
- Not being able to practice against DLC characters in Practice Mode which consequentially brings me to...
- DLC characters being hyper carry machines getting people to the Intermediate ranks with zero effort, knowledge or experience required
- Hitboxes being atrociously large enforcing buttons over movement (counter intuitive to what Tekken has been known for, even those outside of the Tekken sphere)
- Moves with ridiculously disgusting properties (e.g. Paul df2, safe on block, high crush)
*Imagine removing Lars' old T6/TTT2 style df2 (the fcdf2 in Tekken 7 does not count) only to add moves that are even better than Lars' df2 across the board, with even better risk reward ratio in  a game where safety is priority
- Ridiculous strings, everything jails
- Every move is literally a homing move
- All the characters have hyper wall-carry when it used to be confined to a few characters (Nina, Bryan, Lars, Lee, Dragunov and Kazumi) to name a few, and wall-carry with damage combined is confined to even fewer characters
- Due to movement being bad and everything being tracking, "big plays"(enforcing 50/50's, mixups, and generally chunky attacks that skips neutral) are enforced rather than intricate mindgames and movement 
- Terrible Netcode, "5 bars" is inconsistent and "4 bars" is unplayable
- Panic moves with skewed risk/reward ratio that are also horrendously difficult to punish (e.g. Devil Jin uf4, Lars uf3)
- The oversimplification and overhomogenization of characters due to bad balancing
- Ridiculous favoritism towards certain characters in terms of balacing (e.g. Bryan, Mishimas, Feng, Waifus etc.)

Don't play this game if you're even decent, go play T5,T6, TTT2 or even T7 Vanilla if you want to still play T7

On average this game sucks
[list]
[*]there are no substantial single player modes and content
[*]customization is bad
[*]graphics, character models are bad
[*]paid frame data
[*]no anticheat
[*]your online data is stored localy, so anyone can just copypaste their rank if they lose it
[*]netcode is garbage
[*]when you alt+tab in this game you are basically playing roulette
[*]annoyingly long loadings between matches
[*]50% of the time playing this game i just ruin my mood (50/50, [i]entertainment mixup[/i])
[/list]
[i]But...[/i]
[list]
[*]game is very deep and challenging
[*]very spectacular and hype to watch, if you understand what is going on even a little bit (camera movement and sound design helps a lot in understanding momentum/tempo shifts of a match and such)
[*]game has one of the best animations i've seen in FGs, many characters are using real life martial arts
[*]OST in t7 is good most of the time (but t5 one is unbeatable)
[*]community has some weirdos, but overall i can't say it's that bad. There are a lot of people who are really passionate about this game and franchise (me included)
[*]game feels really special when you get better at it. I didn't experienced such feeling of an accomplishment in any other game
[/list]

Really good game. An old classic that only got better with each installment. But literally unplayable. Full of cheaters and macro-users. There is even software that can artificially cause dropped frames to get an advantage over 'organic' opponents. You can download macros free on the internet. There is no anti-cheat, so you can unironically use cheat engine, and your online rank is saved locally, so you can turn off cloud-sync and replace your save file everytime you lose. It's full of cheaters that will automatically break throws, parry lows and mash out frame-perfect combo after frame-perfect combo, all the way down to 2nd/3rd lowest rank. Your only legitimate matches are in bottom rank and vs AI. Play it with RL friends or see if you can beat super-ai in ranked. Oh boy, I can't wait for Tekken 8.

[h1] MY REVIEW [/h1]

I'd start off by saying that I don't touch the online portion of Tekken 7  much because I'm not that good at this game (yet?) especially with the movement (backdash/wavedash) and I'm trying to learn this game again with stick just to see how far I can get with it, I don't enjoy whiffing and getting juggled to oblivion.

I played this the boys and it was a ton of fun. This game also has Tekken Bowling but I don't have it. There are also crossover characters: Akuma, Geese Howard, Noctis from FFXV and Negan from TWD, I don't have them either, except Akuma. Because of this sometimes it would feel like you're playing a different game but personally I don't mind--except Noctis, fuck Noctis and I really like the new Tekken characters, especially Lidia. Now onto things I don't like about this game. The customization leaves a lot to be desired, there's a lot of t-shirt just with different prints and the prints are not unique to each character, each of them has the same t-shirt. The DLC characters never got character story in story mode (probably because people didn't care much about it but cmon it's new characters!), I learned of this when I bought Lidia. The frame data, which should be free, especially in a fighting game is a DLC here, unless you get an edition that comes with it, I didn't. Personally I would have liked it if we could at least grind for some of the characters to unlock them similar to SFV but that's probably just me. 

[h1] PROS [/h1]
+ Different Play Modes (Story, Arcade, Treasure Battle, Online, etc.).
+ Guest characters (Akuma, Geese Howard, Noctis Lucis Caelum and Negan).
+ New Tekken characters (Lidia being my favorite).

[h1] CONS [/h1]
*UPDATE* - requires 80GB of storage, meanwhile SF6 only requires 60 GB storage
- Customization leaves a lot to be desired (T-shirt galore).
- DLC characters have no character story in story mode.
-- Frame Data is a DLC (unless you get an edition that comes with it).

5th August 2023.
7/10. Buy if you like Tekken, but won't change your mind if you don't.
Warning: online is slowly dying, so only get on sale or wait for Tekken 8.
I've played 643.9 hours at this point and I'm in the Red ranks, so I don't know tournament or expert play that well.
## Pros ##
- Regular patches have generally been pretty good at balancing the game
- Large diversity of characters means there is probably a character with moves to suit you
- There's always more to learn, which I find fun
- Legacy players are rewarded
## Neutral ##
- For a 2017 game, environments look good but faces and expression could be alot better so overall graphics are okay
- Decent music, could be more diverse and distinctive but the vibe is basically RAVE RAVE RAVE which is fine
- I overall have a meh opinion on stages. There's few are distinctive and functional stages (examples: Vermillion Gates and Souj) and a few that are too distracting and busy (example: Arena and Mishima Building). Most are just meh though. Generally designs are limited to infinite (no walls) or small (many walls) or 2 small stages between one balcony break with the odd exception. This is serviceable to play but not very diverse.
## Cons ##
In order:
- Netcode is slow - be prepared to wait
- Punishments for pluggers are too arbitrary (hitting legit players) and are generally ineffective
- Lack of modes. Bring back Team Battle!
- Lack of fresh features to fights. Rage Arts and Rage Drive do add something but everything else we've seen before.
- Some DLC should clearly be included in the base game like paying extra for legacy characters and paying for offline only stages. Also Tekken Bowl sucks (3/5 on the scumometer)
- Round breaking weird glitches at the wall
- Hard for beginners e.g. no tutorial, AI is trash so you can't really get a good start offline
- Story mode is TERRIBLE - short (around 4 hours), bad story, bad AI, predictable. Again, hard for beginners.

I hate to say it, but in 2023 Tekken 7's online PC experience is pretty awful. The game itself is fun, challenging, and interesting. It's extremely different from Street Fighter, Guilty Gear, Dragon Ball FighterZ, or any other 2D fighter you can name. The pacing is more deliberate, the mechanics reward thoughtfulness and knowledge in a way that other games can't match, and there's a definite feeling of reward when you learn to master even basic skills like whiff and block punishing, which are virtually required for solid technique. The game isn't easy, but when you start to get a feel for the movement, the 3D environment, and the way combos string together, it becomes very addicting.

But try taking that online on the PC and you're bound to run into a lot of frustrating experiences, including smurfing, save data hacking (which allows higher ranked players to stay in lower ranks and grief opponents), mid-match disconnects, actual macro cheating that the developers have done almost nothing to stop (instant low guard, instant low parry, flawless counter-hits, macros in general, overlays that provide frame data, etc.) and some of the cheesiest cheese you're bound to see in any fighting game anywhere. The latter is a problem in a lot of fighting games and arguably a hurdle you have to surmount no matter what game you're playing. But the cheese options in Tekken 7 make SF6 Blanka look like 19th century poetry. New to the game? It's extremely likely some characters can beat you with just two moves. Not joking. Taht stuff is punishable, but do you want to spend your time memorizing frame data for one character's moveset when every character in the game has 60+ moves? And don't count on getting a rematch if you figure someone out. The second you bust up their goofy strings, they bail. It's not much fun.

Even if there were no cheese or cheating, good luck finding a competitive match in the low ranks right now because if you don't fight a smurf with years of experience, you're likely to fight someone who will pull the plug on their Internet connection the moment they start losing. Even in higher ranks, there's an awful lot of toxicity. 

Other games have these problems too, at least to some extent, but in Tekken 7 on the PC... it sticks out like a gigantic sore thumb.

You've no doubt gotten reviews from professional Tekken 7 players that have put in thousands of hours. Those testimonies are a mixture of both unrequited love and seething hatred. Tekken 7 has been a different game at different stages in its' development just as we are different people at various points in our lives! Anyway,here's a review from a total scrub whom likes fighters but doesn't pursue them as an e-sport career choice!

I'll level, I'm not a fan of the current business model when it comes to fighting games. You put down money for the core foundation and then season passes get released adding characters,modes,and outfits. In my day there was no way for a game to receive internet updates so it came to us in a much more complete state. "Extra content" was unlocked
merely by meeting certain requirements whilst playing. While certain fighters did have those annoying "super turbo alpha editions" releases a few months to a year later the price was quickly reduced because the devs and corpos knew they had to throw us a complimentary bone for buying the previous iterations. It was still a bit shady and a bit anti-consumer but compared to how things are now I wish we could jump into a time-machine and travel back to the friggin 90's!

Having gotten that off my chest,Bandai Namco make great fighting games. At the very least if you can weather the storm and wait until the penultimate definitive version drops then goes on sale you are in for a very good time. I did that previously with Soul Calibur 6 and it is one of the rare gems that stayed on my pc consistently after I downloaded it. I've put around 33+ hours into that tale of souls and swords without being a super competitive "FGC" champion.

Tekken 7 Definitive edition will offer you the following.....

+An enormous  roster. Many old favorites and many brand new faces. You will not be left wanting when it comes to variety.

+A beautiful presentation. Characters look great,backgrounds look great,"everything" looks great. 

+ The fighting game mechanics are easy to understand. You do not have to feel intimidated. The tutorials and even the story mode lay it all out in simple terms. However, though Tekken is noob friendly it is still a momentous task to master. Be aware of that before choosing a higher difficulty or going online.

+Guest characters play just like they do in their respective franchises. I was pleasantly surprised by that after taking Akuma for a spin. 

+By the way, I thought the plot and narrative were presented better than certain people give them credit for. If you like cyberpunk,mysterious shadowy organizations,scary Japanese folk-lore,supernatural shenanigans,messed up family dramas,and epic biblical revelations tier end-of-the world scenarios Tekken 7 certainly goes hard...

+Treasure mode is my jam. Earning in game gold to unlock a wealth of extra content has always appealed to my inner dragon. (Get it? Dragons like hoards of plundered riches!)

+Most of the men are masculine. Most of the women are feminine. There's also diverse representation without sycophantic pointless pandering. Sexy and cool looking outfits can be unlocked for both genders. And you know what? No normal people in any demographic have a beef with this. (Perfectly balanced as all things should be!) 

+There are certain sequences in story mode where you can mow down incoming baddies with actual guns. No joke! (America,frick yeah!)

+Narcoleptic sleepy goth vampire girl ended up being more endearing than I thought she would be!

+You have your throws,reversals,high jabs,low jabs,high kicks,low kicks,mid attacks,juggles,pins,side-steps,holds,grapples,and near-death desperation specials.  Despite Tekken being equal parts "SCP",robot-wars,horror themed family soap opera,bear-brawling,and monster-mash the moment to moment fisticuffs are grounded in realistic martial arts fundamentals. (Er,mostly!)

+One of the better Tekken soundtracks to date. Props to the composers! 

Gripes

-Julia Chang has become a youtuber. (Like and subscribe!) Why? Wasn't she originally a humble ecologist outdoors tom-boy type?

-Kazumi is gonna knock you out! Kazumi gonna scream and shout! Kazumi gonna let her tiger roam about!
 
-"Bro,that's not my final devil form! "This" is! Peeeeeeeeeeeew!"

-Tekken bowling? (Suppresses Iori-like maniacal laughter) Alright I'll level,it's "kinda" fun! But y'know,we could have gotten a refined "beat em up mode" similar to the one in Tekken 6 with more polish! Yeah,that would have been swell.

-No tag-team mode. I realize this isn't a Tekken-Tag entry but it would have been so easy to include. I briefly played the tag-mode in DOA 5 and it was a delight. Shame something similar is missing here.

-Story mode despite its' high production values is "short". Enjoyable but short. Additionally not every character got a fleshed out prologue/epilogue. I feel as if previous Tekken games handled this better. The Mishima saga stuff has top tier production values and visual spectacle in spades but the ball was dropped elsewhere. I compare all this to an entertaining block-buster movie you see with your friends. Fun was had by all but if you take a moment to  think about it "honestly" the presentation was much better than the overall plot and the character development.

-Certain outfits cost "a lot of money" when in comparison to others without rhyme or reason.

-Negan. Negan?! He fits well enough into Tekken's war-torn world whilst simultaneously sticking out like a sore thumb. Was there that much overlap between fighting fans and Walking Dead fans? You have to admit,Negan is an odd inclusion. I mean we could have had Mai Shiranui,Jun,Jinpachi,Iori Yagami,Cammy White,Chun Li,Terry Bogard,or "anyone else" instead....

(Glad they at least put in Armor-King. I thought he was left out but then realized he made the cut!)

Neutral

+/- "Smurfing" in the competitive online circuit. That's when someone logs out at the cusp of defeat so they don't drop in their ranking. To some folks that is going to be infuriating.

However, if you enjoy fighters non-competitively and would not be caught dead at an EVO event even if someone paid you then it's not an issue.

To me "rank and trophies" only mean something if you train at the gym and win in a "real" martial arts tournament. That takes dedication and skill. Not just of mind but of body and spirit too.

When I play a fighting game it is just a hobby. It's escapism. Its' letting my inner child let off some steam so I can better cope with the harshness of the real world. It is something I do but it does not define my value. As such I do not take it seriously!

Brief summary of my history with Tekken

Played every entry starting with 2 onward. Yes, I even remember when Bonk was an unlockable character! (The little orange dinosaur!) 

My favorite entry ever was Tekken 5. 4 and 6 were alright but presented new fledgling ideas in awkward ways that were hit or miss. (2,Tag,and 3 were also pinnacles of the series at its' best.)

So far for me Tekken 7 Definitive edition is almost tied with Tekken 5. It is certainly better in most ways compared to 4 and 6.

PS: Love what you do Bandai/Namco! Word of advice. Don't update your games years later with unnecessary censorship just to appeal to "The modern audience". The blood in the water you are now seeing is from new Skull-Girls devs clowning around doing just that. Let it be a lesson for future generations.

Chilli con carne recipe

if you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding Chilli con carne recipe you've come to the right place,

Ingredients

1 large onion
1 red pepper
2 garlic cloves
1 tbsp oil
1 heaped tsp hot chilli powder (or 1 level tbsp if you only have mild)

1 tsp paprika
1 tsp ground cumin
500g lean minced beef
1 beef stock cube
400g can chopped tomatoes
¬Ω tsp dried marjoram
1 tsp sugar (or add a thumbnail-sized piece of dark chocolate along with the beans instead, see tip)

2 tbsp tomato pur√©e
410g can red kidney beans
plain boiled long grain rice, to serve
soured cream, to serve

Directions

STEP 1
Prepare your vegetables. Chop 1 large onion into small dice, about 5mm square. The easiest way to do this is to cut the onion in half from root to tip, peel it and slice each half into thick matchsticks lengthways, not quite cutting all the way to the root end so they are still held together. Slice across the matchsticks into neat dice.

STEP 2
Cut 1 red pepper in half lengthways, remove stalk and wash the seeds away, then chop. Peel and finely chop 2 garlic cloves.

STEP 3
Start cooking. Put your pan on the hob over a medium heat. Add 1 tbsp oil and leave it for 1-2 minutes until hot (a little longer for an electric hob).

STEP 4
Add the onion and cook, stirring fairly frequently, for about 5 minutes, or until the onion is soft, squidgy and slightly translucent.

STEP 5
Tip in the garlic, red pepper, 1 heaped tsp hot chilli powder or 1 level tbsp mild chilli powder, 1 tsp paprika and 1 tsp ground cumin.

STEP 6
Give it a good stir, then leave it to cook for another 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.

STEP 7
Brown 500g lean minced beef. Turn the heat up a bit, add the meat to the pan and break it up with your spoon or spatula. The mix should sizzle a bit when you add the mince.

STEP 8
Keep stirring and prodding for at least 5 minutes, until all the mince is in uniform, mince-sized lumps and there are no more pink bits. Make sure you keep the heat hot enough for the meat to fry and become brown, rather than just stew.

STEP 9
Make the sauce. Crumble 1 beef stock cube into 300ml hot water. Pour this into the pan with the mince mixture.


info.
This great chilli recipe has to be one of the best dishes to serve to friends for a casual get-together. An easy sharing favourite that uses up storecupboard ingredients.
it's also freezable

Tekken 7, developed and published by Bandai Namco Entertainment, is an exhilarating and visually stunning fighting game that showcases the pinnacle of the long-standing Tekken franchise. With its deep and satisfying combat mechanics, diverse character roster, and breathtaking visuals, Tekken 7 offers a fighting experience that is both accessible to newcomers and rewarding to seasoned veterans.

One of the standout features of Tekken 7 is its refined and polished combat system. The game strikes a delicate balance between accessibility and depth, allowing players of all skill levels to enjoy its fast-paced and adrenaline-fueled battles. The intuitive controls and responsive inputs ensure that executing moves and combos feels smooth and satisfying, while the intricacies of timing, spacing, and character-specific strategies provide a high skill ceiling for competitive play. Tekken 7's combat system rewards precision, timing, and knowledge of character matchups, making each bout a thrilling and strategic dance of fists.

The character roster of Tekken 7 is both diverse and memorable. Featuring a mix of classic favorites and new additions, each fighter boasts a unique set of moves, playstyle, and personality. From the lightning-fast strikes of Hwoarang to the unyielding power of Heihachi, there is a fighter to suit every player's preferences and playstyle. Additionally, the game introduces exciting new characters such as Kazumi Mishima and the enigmatic Leroy Smith, adding fresh dynamics and surprises to the already robust roster.

Visually, Tekken 7 is a breathtaking spectacle. The graphics are stunning, with detailed character models, vibrant stages, and impressive visual effects. The dynamic camera angles and slow-motion sequences during intense moments of battle further enhance the cinematic experience, immersing players in the heart-pounding action. The attention to detail in the stages and character animations showcases the developers' dedication to creating a visually immersive world.

The single-player content in Tekken 7 offers a compelling and engaging experience. The story mode delves into the Mishima family saga, presenting a cinematic narrative that ties together the complex relationships between the iconic characters. The inclusion of additional single-player modes, such as arcade mode, treasure battle, and customization options, provides hours of enjoyment and replayability beyond the competitive multiplayer.

Speaking of multiplayer, Tekken 7's online modes offer a robust and lag-free experience. Whether engaging in ranked matches or casual battles, the online matchmaking system ensures fair and balanced matchups. The ability to compete against players from around the world adds an extra layer of challenge and excitement, as players can test their skills and strive for victory in a competitive environment.

In conclusion, Tekken 7 is a fighting masterpiece that sets a new standard for the genre. Its refined combat mechanics, diverse character roster, and breathtaking visuals make it an essential experience for both casual players and competitive fighting game enthusiasts. Whether you're unleashing devastating combos, perfecting your defensive skills, or immersing yourself in the rich narrative of the Mishima family, Tekken 7 delivers an adrenaline-fueled, pulse-pounding experience that will keep you coming back for more. Prepare to enter the King of Iron Fist Tournament and prove your worth as the ultimate fighter in this electrifying and unforgettable game.

For about an hour this was a negative review. Then I returned after cooling off and changed it to this positive one. This game can be infuriating at times but overall it's my favorite of any fighting game and it's the only one that's ever really stuck for me. There are so many levels to game-play that really give it a lot of longevity compared to other games in the genre, and it's a great platform to come up with some of your own creative fighting styles. Its unique sort of creative expression can be singularly satisfying in its good moments. Overall I would recommend, just be careful about who you choose to play when starting off, some characters are certainly much more of a struggle than others. And if you're like me and this game is your introduction to fighting games, maybe be prepared to embrace masochism.

I love Tekken, I've been with it since Tekken 5, which doesn't sound like much but this game really does have a special place in my heart especially Tekken 6. But how the heck did Bandai Namco manage to devolve this thing? First of all, the character roster is fine albeit having some weird guest appearances here like frickin Negan from The Walking Dead. 

But the real problem lies within the moveset, I swear the Rage Art is too OP and feels like a cheap way to win against opponents, and I think it should be removed from future games. Another thing would be that most of the characters, specifically the newer ones like Negan, Kunimitsu II, Akuma and especially Leroy (and good God so much more) have such braindead, button-mashy movesets that requires no effort to pull off ridiculous combos, and it just feels so unfair because it does not feel earned to be able to do these moves for someone that can't even perform a 10 hit combo like myself. I feel like there should be some changes to how these characters perform their attacks, perhaps make it harder? or more varied? like come on Kunimitsu can initiate a 5 to 6 hit combo for just spamming Triangle for crying out loud, and it ends with enemy faceplanting making them vulnerable to another barrage of unfair attacks.

And I haven't even started on Leroy! I read somewhere a dude won a tournament despite only using Leroy for a week... A WEEK.

Next, the story. Now the main story is fine, I don't keep up much with Tekken lore but form what I saw, it's fine. But what is with the story mode for the other characters? Why is it only limited to a few characters? In past games, every character had a story mode, complete with a prologue and an epilogue, but now we just get a few of them. 

Next is online... don't. 

Lastly, the customization. What the hell happened here? Why is it so limited? most of the clothes suck and you can't really make anything wacky or outstanding with them. I don't know man, it just doesn't have the same freedom that we used to get in older entries of the series.

The only reason I will ever tell someone to get this is that it's kinda fun to play with your friends at home. At full price, it's just not worth it. Get it on sale. Or just wait for Tekken 8, hopefully it's good.

[h1]Tekken 7 Review - Is It Worth It In 2023?[/h1]

With the recent announcement of Tekken 8, the hype train for the franchise‚Äôs upcoming installment has been kicked into high gear. Although Tekken 8 deserves all the hype that it‚Äôs getting, maybe it‚Äôs also time we took a look back at Tekken 7 and asked ourselves, ‚ÄúHow good was it?‚Äù

In this review, we‚Äôll be taking a look at all the changes that Tekken 7 has undergone throughout its lifespan and see whether or not it‚Äôs still worth getting in 2023. I‚Äôve been playing Tekken since year 1, so rest assured I‚Äôll be providing an unbiased and highly critical review of the game that will highlight all the pros and cons.

[h1]About Tekken 7[/h1]

Originally released in February 2015, Tekken 7 is the latest installment in the highly acclaimed Tekken franchise by Bandai Namco. Tekken 7 is a 3D fighting game that puts a high emphasis on character movement and character knowledge, emphasizing the unique characteristics of each fighter (and surprise, 2 bears).

This release features a long-awaited crossover in the form of Street Fighter‚Äôs own raging demon: Akuma. Of course, this has raised everyone‚Äôs hopes for the long-awaited Tekken x Street Fighter, but it seems this is the closest we‚Äôre getting to that dream.

Regardless, Tekken 7 stands as one of the best selling entries into the franchise with over 9 million sales, and only 2 million of those sales coming in 2021 alone. The game is still going strong following the latest update (version 5.00) released in August 2022, which introduced a new wall combo mechanic and tons of balance changes to go along with it.

So now the question is: Should you join the 5,000 players still playing the game?

[h1]Tekken 7 Story[/h1]

Following where Tekken 6 left off, Jin Kazama started a global conflict in order to summon and ultimately defeat the origin of the devil gene, hoping to finally rid himself of this genetic curse. Unfortunately, as with every other attempt to eliminate the devil gene, this plan failed  leaving Jin Kazama exhausted and on the sidelines.

Tekken 7 follows the lives of the present-day Mishima family through the eyes of a third-person character, simply named ‚ÄúThe Journalist‚Äù. It follows the father-son relationship of Heihachi Mishima and Kazuya Mishima and the origin of their grudge against each other.

Tekken 7‚Äôs main story mode is entertaining but leaves a lot to be desired. The flow of events and motivations for each character is unorganized and often confusing. The story is made even more confusing by adding the element of The Journalist‚Äôs personal story, something that I‚Äôm sure most fans (including myself) have no interest in at all. I mean, who cares about a random journalist when there are a bunch of martial artists fighting around the world?

Although the Mishima bloodline story is very interesting, part of me wishes that they also emphasized the other characters‚Äô stories. Out of the 51 characters in Tekken 7‚Äôs final roster, only 10 are featured in the main campaign.

The Mishima bloodline elements of the story were still very entertaining and worth playing through, but please just trim off all the fat and just give us the characters that we‚Äôre already familiar with. We just want to see muscular fighters punching each other!
 
[h1]Tekken 7 Gameplay[/h1]

Tekken 7‚Äôs online mode features both unranked and ranked matches that test your skills against an opponent from anywhere in the world. The offline mode features just as much satisfaction, featuring the Treasure Battle mode, which pits you against CPU opponents that reward you cosmetics or in-game currency on a defeat.

Each player plays a different version of their character, both technically and aesthetically. Tekken 7 offers a robust customization mode featuring unique cosmetics across all characters to ensure that your character looks the way that you want them to look. Want your character to look like Link from The Legend of Zelda? You can! Want to bring a gun to a fistfight? Go right ahead!

The only thing missing would be a proper tutorial mode. Any random player could pick up Tekken 7 with absolutely no experience with the past Tekken games and still have a blast, and that entertainment will only get better as their knowledge of character moves increases. It just so happens that in order to increase your character knowledge, you have to reach out to 3rd party sources to fully interpret all the tools that your character has.
 
[h1]Tekken 7 Combat[/h1]

Tekken 7 is a 3D fighting game, which means, unlike games like Street Fighter or Mortal Kombat, you can move around the foreground and background. Tekken 7 also offers a satisfying combo system that rewards technical skill with flashy combos. That said, the move list for each character can be quite lengthy and overwhelming especially for new players.

Learning a character involves knowing the punishes, pokes, and combos of each character. Once you‚Äôve got the knowledge, next comes the application. Put your knowledge to the test to poke and punish your way to victory!
 
[h1]Tekken 7 Quest/Mission System[/h1]

To be the best, just like in everything, you have to be willing to put in the work. Grind your way to the very top of the rank mountain, all the way from the ‚ÄúBeginner‚Äù rank to Tekken God Omega by stomping on anyone that dares stand in your way. No one likes getting steamrolled online, especially in Tekken. With the high skill ceiling, it‚Äôs easy to feel helpless during a match. Thankfully, Bandai Namco‚Äôs ranking system makes sure that you‚Äôre matched with a player who is on your skill level.

[h1]Tekken 7 Graphics[/h1]

Tekken 7 is the first entry in the franchise to be created in Unreal Engine 4, and the graphics live up to the name. Character models look the best that they have ever been, even featuring cool little details like fabric simulations and costumes that change throughout the fight. But characters aren‚Äôt the only thing you‚Äôll be feasting your eyes on: there are also the beautiful stages to fight on. Mishima Dojo remains a personal favorite because of the progressive damage the stage undergoes throughout the battle.

[h1]Tekken 7 Developer[/h1]

Bandai Namco first announced the development of Tekken 7 at EVO 2014, and the game has been taken care of ever since. Bandai Namco is also famous for games such as the Naruto fighting games, Ace Combat, and Soul Calibur. Bandai Namco, or Bamco for short, has rolled out tons of additional content to increase the longevity of the game in the form of new characters, stages, and game modes. Although all that extra content does come at a price, the free balance updates are amazing enough on their own. Fair warning though, if you plan on getting Tekken 7 right now, prepare for a lack of updates in the future. It seems that while Tekken 7 has gone strong for multiple years since release, its life as the main focus of Bamco‚Äôs development team could be coming to an end.

[h1]Tekken 7 Price[/h1]

Tekken 7 base game without all the DLC costs $25, while the Definitive Edition will cost you around $72 for Steam, Xbox, and PS4. Personally? I would go with Tekken 7 base game and just buy the DLC characters and stages that interest me. This is ideal because some Tekken 7 characters on release are broken and overpowered, making the game pay to win for a while. Fortunately for us, Bandai Namco balances these overpowered characters quickly. Thank you, Bandai Namco!

[h1] Verdict[/h1]

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
  [*]Low skill floor makes it easy to enjoy with friends.
  [*]High skill ceiling means you‚Äôll have a blast learning the game.
  [*]Beautiful graphics.
  [*]A huge roster of characters.
  [*]Progression can be very satisfying.
[/list]
[b]CONS:[/b]
[list]
  [*]Lack of single-player game modes
  [*]Disappointing story
  [*]Moderately buggy online mode
  [*]The game provides no support in improving. Want a tutorial? Go watch a Youtube video.
[/list]

Tekken 7 is a thrilling and polished fighting game that delivers a satisfying blend of deep gameplay mechanics and competitive action. With its diverse roster of characters, each with their unique fighting styles and movesets, the game offers a wealth of options for players to explore and master. The visuals are stunning, with detailed character models and beautifully rendered stages that add to the immersive experience. The online multiplayer component provides a robust and engaging competitive scene, offering endless opportunities for intense battles. While the story mode could have been more fleshed out, Tekken 7's solid gameplay, impressive visuals, and strong multiplayer offerings make it a standout title in the fighting game genre. With its tight combat mechanics and thrilling multiplayer battles, Tekken 7 earns a solid 8/10 rating.

This game has ever since brought me and my pet rock closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Easy pancakes

if you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pancakes recipe you've come to the right place,

Ingredients

100g plain flour

2 large eggs

300ml milk

1 tbsp sunflower or vegetable oil, plus a little extra for frying

optional
lemon wedges to serve (optional)
caster sugar to serve (optional)


Directions

STEP 1
Put 100g plain flour, 2 large eggs, 300ml milk, 1 tbsp sunflower or vegetable oil and a pinch of salt into a bowl or large jug, then whisk to a smooth batter.

STEP 2
Set aside for 30 mins to rest if you have time, or start cooking straight away.

STEP 3
Set a medium frying pan or cr√™pe pan over a medium heat and carefully wipe it with some oiled kitchen paper.

STEP 4
When hot, cook your pancakes for 1 min on each side until golden, keeping them warm in a low oven as you go.

STEP 5
Serve with lemon wedges and caster sugar, or your favourite filling. Once cold, you can layer the pancakes between baking parchment, then wrap in cling film and freeze for up to 2 months:-


Tip :)
Sift the flour in (ie. pour the flour into a sieve and then tap or gently shake the sieve until all the flour has gone through it. Some larger clumps of flour may require you to rub them between your fingers or against the sieve grating to break them up) this will vastly reduce the number of clumps of flour and make it much easier to whisk it together.

This is the best fighting game currently on the market. By a long shot. It is super complex, but for those somewhat experienced in fighting games it isn't that hard to get into. The combo system is amazing, and every time you hit a massive move or a big counter-hit launcher the game makes sure you know you did a good thing. Every character is super different in playstyles, even if some of them have similar moves (Mishima/Law types). And has (almost) no projectiles to be seen, and even in the 2 exceptions sidestepping is an option. Essentially, all the stupid shit from many fighting games today aren't really present. So, essentially, if you are a Cetrion or JP main, this game may not be for you. For anyone else, I highly recommend it for casual and competitive fighting game players.

tekken finally has a pcport and it's fantastic   the entire version is objectively the best with fantastic graphics  short loadtimes and tons of peripheral support  this is a perfect example of a series transitioning to pc if you like fightinggames  this is an absolute mustbuy   fantastic mechanics that are fun for all   tekken has a low barrier to entry  but a massive skillceiling  you can buy this game and have a fantastic time even if you have never played a fighting game before  for the serious player the game features insane depth and a lot to enjoy  tekken 7 has changed things such as throwbreaking and made things generally more streamlined  but maintained it's complexety and depth  this really is the best tekken has ever been    optimized roster   while not perfect  the roster is tightened up  your favorite is most likely still in the game and the newcomers are generally good  each character feels unique and i feel namco has made good decisions on which characters to keep    hype as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• final boss   just play the story and see for yourself    lack of content in general   i would like to underline that this game has already been out for 2 years in arcades  while not the frversion  the game has techinally been complete  this begs the question of what in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• namco has been doing for 2 years  customization is a joke compared to tekken 6 and there are very few modes  there is also no replaymode or anything outside the basic ranked online    the storymode is very short and the scenarios for other characters are just abysmal  these scenarios are basically a random fight with an inengine cutcene that does the bare minimum of fanservice  every tekkengame before this has had far more fleshed out content storywise in general  also  the customization is especially sadening considering that there are so few characters and one would assume this means more options for each one    mediocre storymode   the storymode is short and nothing to really brag about  it has some cool moments (and akuma)  but it's basically a bunch of cgcutcenes tied together with a terrible narrator and a hamfisted plot  the story makes no sense  but i can't really fault the game for it  tekken has always been bonkers  however  compared to many other fighters it really falls flat and it has to be pointed out considering that the game offers very little other content    no tutorials or help for newcomers   the game has absolutely no tutorial and it's honestly baffling  tekken is not an easy game to get into  sure you can mash buttons as eddy  but there is only a question of time until someone bodies you  it's easy to feel lost in this game  yet the game makes very little effort to teach you anything  you are going to end up on youtube and other sites to figure out combos  framedata etc  and that isn't good  there should at least be something here to teach new players the basics    online has flaws   as of writing this there are several big problems with online that will hopefully be fixed soon  first of all  ragequitting is a serious problem  there is basically no punishment for quitting and if a player disconnects on you  you don't get the win  this becomes an even bigger problem in tekkens tournamentmode  if the host gets mad he can kick you immediately or outright leave to shut down the entire lobby  as a result  playing tournamentmode is rather difficult    connecting to other players is also very difficult as of right now  connecting through the matchlist is almost hopeless and filled with error messages  the best option is using warmup and wait for a match to be suggested by the matchmaking system  however  this is also frustratingly difficult  it can take 34 requests before you can accept a request to fight that actually works  as a result you will often end up in games with 3bar connections because the game has not been able to connect to the players that fit the criteria you searched for  most of the time you will be told that "the connection to the opponent has been lost"  you might think that this is your potential opponent declining your request  but in the majority of times it is in fact the game struggling to connect  however  this will most likely be fixed and when it happens i will remove this from the review the game follows the events of the king of iron fist tournament hosted by the mishima zaibatsu where players control a plethora of characters to win the tournament and gain control of the company the conflict between the mishima family serves as the main focus of the series plot while players explore other characters motivations in aiming to control the zaibatsu   gameplay focuses on handtohand combat with an opponent with the gameplay system including blocks throws escapes and ground fighting. the series later introduced combos and special moves with characters also able to stage break arenas  it was also revealed that heihachi killed his wife kazumi in selfdefense because of her possession of the devil gene and the fact that she had gained a split personality because of it shortly after kazuya was born

decent offline game
bad online.

[Decent]
- The Max Level difficulty in story mode is unbelievably hard (of course) but the satisfaction you get from beating it is amazing.
- The customisation options are top notch as usual - if not even more in depth than in previous games.
- The main story and the way it's told from a sort of outside perspective is really intriguing and detailed.
- Perfect game to play while waiting for your friends to get on and play some other multiplayer games.

[Bad]
- The game features an easy combo system; where you hold L1/Left Bumper/whatever it is on PC, and press any of the 4 buttons to do 4 different easy combos that would otherwise take practise to perform in a fight, or has a lot of buttons to execute (and you can link them together of course). 
You can do this in the ONLINE mode... Why in the absolute fkn world are you able to do this? It makes the online fights completely stale and not even remotely entertaining - just full well knowing you are getting deleted purely by somebody pressing singular buttons like it's a QTE. I genuinely cannot get over how ridiculous this is. I would pass this even if you could only do it in the casual/non-ranked mode, but you can do it competitive matches.

- The individual character stories are insanely uninspired and makes some of the coolest rivalries, seem extremely redundant. It often features the two characters (lets say for example Hwoarang and Devil Jin) that are next to each other in the menu. You play one, a bunch of text comes up, you enter the fight, you win, and a cheesy cutscene plays. You then select the other character, a bunch of text comes up, you enter the fight, you win, and then see a different cheesy cutscene. It's painful compared to some of the scenes we have seen before in previous Tekken games. It's still sort of cool, but becomes completely unforgivable when you realise what they could have been.

Don't buy this game looking for a good online experience. 
It's perfect if you care about the Mishima storyline, and that's honestly about it.

Stop releasing DLC and come out with a new game, it's been 4 years.

[EDIT: 56 Hrs Total]

Ignore Decent points 2 & 3. I went back and played T6 and TTT2 and the customisation of this game PALES in comparison. Also rescinding my take on the story; specifically the Mishima storyline - purely because they made Akuma canon. Unbelievable.

I take back my entire 'Bad' point about the easy combos. Yes, it's so cheap and still frustrating to see it happen - but it's literally a skill issue. I just learned the match ups and counter most of them when the other player is just spamming them. I'm still bad but am getting better.

tekken 7 is the most frustrating game in the entire series. with obnoxious tools, and bad/oily movement which makes it way harder to deal with mashing unless you are at the skill level where you can naturally recognize gaps in strings to take back your turn, or can comfortably recognize when a low is about to clip you, the game ends up feeling way worse for newer players when defending compared to just being really fast like in tekken tag 2, and ending up being to the absolute left of someone when they pressed at the wrong time. it's not impossible to step things in this game, it's just way riskier because a lot of good tools track, and do an incredibly high amount of damage if you're hit by them. and, with cool DLC guest appearances from characters like, geese howard from fatal fury, marduk from tekken, ganryu from tekken, or even julia from tekken, you get to lose in such a way where you don't quite know whether or not the other guy is just way better than you, or if he just paid 5 bucks to play as a better character.


but, when compared to tekken tag 2 which was the most frustrating game in the entire series, due to it being the first video game with over four billion characters, all of which having 500 thousand moves you'd have to figure out and learn how to defend against with your own pair of two characters with 500 thousand moves. annoying bruce eddy teams/very fun double capo hypertension dead at 24 yo. teams, or playing against the absurd mishimas, which - if i remember correctly - were awful to play against due to ridiculous TTT2 movement, and tag electric combos which did an unusually high amount of damage to red health when compared to most other tag combos. there was also the very fun tag assault mechanic which ensured that you at minimum took 60% of your health in one combo at all times. i think this game's netcode was better than tekken 7's however.


now, compared to tekken 6, which was the most frustrating game in the entire series - but that was more so due to bob, law and lars, and how oppressive they could be online and offline. as well as most characters having a way to blow you up totally randomly if the wrong things were to happen - it's still fairly frustrating.

(tekken 7 mysteriously somehow had a top 8 with more of a single character than this game too. 4 bobs in T6 evo 2011 top 8, and 6 leroys in T7 evo japan 2020 top 8. and you know what else is funny? tekken 7's bob is absolutely way stronger than tekken 6's bob, he never got nerfed accordingly, he's just not very good compared to everyone else in this game. leroy was nerfed accordingly, however. he's no longer nearly as oppressive.)

still, when compared to games like tekken revolution, which stats' system made it the most frustrating game in the entire series, it's pretty good.

however, tekken 7 on the other hand? this is my favorite game in the series.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

6 tablespoons unsalted butter

1/2 cup white sugar

1/2 cup brown sugar

1/4 cup water

1/4 teaspoon cinnamon

1 pinch salt

5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced

1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.

Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

If you're looking for a game that will make you question your ability to properly press buttons, then Tekken 7 is the one for you! From the moment I fired it up on Steam, I knew I was in for a hilarious journey of triumphs, defeats, and accidental button presses that would make any pro-gamer cringe.

Let's start with the character selection screen. It's like a buffet of pure awesomeness, but instead of food, you're choosing between a sword fielding alien, a flamboyant breakdancer, and an angry panda with martial arts skills. I mean, who needs logic when you can unleash a bear on your opponent, right?

Now, let's talk about the fighting mechanics. It's a delicate dance between timing, strategy, and plain old button mashing. I couldn't help but feel like a genius when I pulled off an epic combo, even though I had no clue what I was doing. And when I lost? Well, it was clearly because my fingers didn't possess the superhuman speed required to pull off those devastating moves. Yeah, let's blame it on the fingers!

The graphics in Tekken 7 are stunning. Every character is so detailed that you can practically count the pixels in their sweat droplets. It's truly a marvel to watch as your favorite fighter gets punched in the face so hard that their hair flies in slow motion. Who needs realistic physics when you can have gravity-defying hairstyles?

The game modes provide endless entertainment. Story mode offers a narrative that's more convoluted than a telenovela, but hey, we're not here for deep storytelling, are we? We're here to punch our way through a roster of colorful characters and pretend we're a legendary warrior. And don't even get me started on the online multiplayer battles. Nothing says "friendship" like beating your best buddy to a pulp from the comfort of your own home.

But let's address the elephant in the room: the rage quits. Tekken 7 has the power to turn the most serene individuals into raging beasts. The satisfaction of landing a perfect combo and watching your opponent's health bar deplete rapidly is unparalleled. Unfortunately, that feeling is swiftly replaced by the sound of a controller smashing against the wall when your friend suddenly disconnects because they can't handle your superior fighting skills.

In conclusion, Tekken 7 is a hilarious and addictive fighting game that will make you question your sanity and your reflexes. It's a button-mashing extravaganza filled with outrageous characters, gravity-defying hairstyles, and enough rage quits to make your therapist proud. So, gather your friends, stock up on spare controllers, and prepare to unleash your inner button masher!

Disclaimer: No controllers were harmed during the writing of this review. Okay, maybe one... but it totally deserved it.

The freedom to modify and tailor the appearance of in-game avatars adds a layer of fun and individuality, enhancing the overall immersion and enjoyment derived from the game. This customization feature contributes to the game's depth and replayability, allowing players to forge a deeper connection with their characters and further immerse themselves in the game world.

[h1]The 100% Tekken 7 Review[/h1]

[table]
[tr]
[td][b]Pros[/b][/td]
[td][b]Cons[/b][/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Stunning visuals and animations that bring the game's characters and stages to life[/td]
[td]The game's story mode is lackluster and fails to provide a meaningful experience for players[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Diverse cast of characters with unique fighting styles and move sets[/td]
[td]The game's online matchmaking can be slow and lead to long wait times[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Deep and complex gameplay mechanics that reward mastery and skill[/td]
[td]The game's difficulty can be daunting for newcomers, making it hard to get into the game[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Variety of game modes including arcade, versus, and tournament modes[/td]
[td]Some players may find the game's DLC practices to be excessive, with additional characters and costumes locked behind paywalls[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Robust customization options that allow players to personalize their favorite characters[/td]
[td]The game's single player content can be repetitive and lackluster, with little to do outside of practicing and training[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][/td]
[td]The game's netcode can be inconsistent and lead to laggy online matches[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][/td]
[td]The game's community can be toxic and unwelcoming to new players[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h3][b]Conclusion:[/b][/h3]

Tekken 7 is a fighting game that boasts stunning visuals and animations, as well as a diverse cast of characters with unique fighting styles and move sets. The gameplay mechanics are deep and complex, rewarding mastery and skill. In addition to the classic arcade and versus modes, Tekken 7 also features a variety of game modes, including a tournament mode, which can be a lot of fun for players who enjoy competing against others.

One downside of the game is its lackluster story mode, which fails to provide a meaningful experience for players. Additionally, the game's online matchmaking can be slow and lead to long wait times, and the netcode can be inconsistent, leading to laggy online matches. Some players may also find the game's DLC practices to be excessive, with additional characters and costumes locked behind paywalls.

The game's difficulty can also be daunting for newcomers, making it hard to get into the game. The single player content can also be repetitive and lackluster, with little to do outside of practicing and training. Furthermore, the game's community can be toxic and unwelcoming to new players, which can make it hard for players to feel comfortable playing online.

Overall, while Tekken 7 has many strengths, including its stunning visuals, diverse cast of characters, and deep gameplay mechanics, it also has several downsides, including a lackluster story mode, slow online matchmaking, and a toxic community. However, for players who enjoy competitive fighting games, Tekken 7 is definitely worth checking out.

[b] [Played for almost 400 hours + Finished all achievements] [/b]
A solid Tekken game that has been ported relatively well for PC since forever.
Let's start with the negatives.
---------------------------------------------------------
Cons:
[list]
 [*][b] DLC favoritism [/b] - If you like the base roster and have no interest in any of the DLC characters made available, then you're going to have a hard time labbing/learning them as Bandai Namco does not allow training mode against them unless you purchase them first.
 [*][b] Somewhat terrible latency issue [/b] - With the most recent updates, the game's already shaky latency issue exacerbated with laggier matches and frequent frame loss.
 [*][b] Frame Data behind a paywall [/b] - A feature that should be available for everyone is behind a paywall for Tekken 7. You need to buy Season Pass 3 in order to get access to the data.
 [*][b] Terrible, I mean, TERRIBLE customization [/b] - Remember when you could make your main character into cool cyber ninjas, medieval knights and sexy nurses in the past? Well, Tekken 7 is mostly recycled pieces with 70% of the options being plain T-shirts. Pathetic.
[/list]
---------------------------------------------------------
Pros:
[list]
 [*][b] Huge roster [/b] - Familiar faces, new faces, guest characters, you name it, Tekken 7 has it. I'm a Zafina player since Tekken 6 and was genuinely surprised when they reintroduced her in 7. The reason why I came back to the franchise.
 [*][b] Average~Good porting [/b] - Most Japanese games have terrible porting since they port a console game into a PC. But Tekken 7 have relatively okay-ish porting with pretty good optimization (except for the Alt + Tab bug).
 [*][b] Decent graphics [/b] - For a game that was made in 2015, the game still holds up to this very day.
 [*][b] TERRIBLE Network [/b] - The network of this game is getting worse update after update. The constant jitters and lags with laughable semi-rollback makes the game more unplayable than playable.
[/list]
All in all, I give it a 5 out of 10.

[h1] TEKKEN 7 Review[/h1]
[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
[b] TEKKEN 7[/b] is a 3D fighter that keeps players entertained through its core of "practice makes perfect," as there is a lot to learn and master in the depth of this title. The stages and music incorporate beautifully on-screen, adding tension and emotion to every match. Paired with the dynamic relation of fast action with a slow tempo, it creates an environment where fights are agitated, and every round counts. Keep reading to know what makes [b]TEKKEN[/b] 7 excellent!

[TABLE]
[TR]
[TH][H3]Pros[/H3][/TH]
[TH][H3]Cons[/H3][/TH]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]
[list]
[*]Characters with unique styles.
[*]Fights tempos are dynamic and tense.
[*]Energetic music that pumps you up.
[*]Great customization options for the roster.
[*]Big roster with great guest characters.
[/list]
[/TD]
[TD]
[list]
[*]The story could have been better.
[*]Graphically, it's below its peers.
[*]Grinding customization can be tiring.
[*] It can take a lot of work to get into for newbies.
[*]DLC can be pretty pricey to acquire.
[/list]
[/TD]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]The Craft of a Singular Style in a Big Roster[/h1]
[b]TEKKEN 7[/b] features an extensive roster with 49 characters! Each of them shares some common ground in their basic gameplay but has unique styles in handling the combat based on their strengths. [b]Noctis[/b], for example, has a high reach that allows him to defend against attacks or keep opponents at bay. In contrast, other fighters as [b]Eliza[/b], can fill bars to increase the power of their moves and behave more erratically. Playing each character, you would realize that despite some singularities, how you move and face opponents will change drastically.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2118894727

In contrast to the gameplay of its roster, I enjoyed the story less in my time with the game; it is not bad itself, but it was pretty short and lacked more content. Overall it did a stable job in terms of quality. Still, it ends up being more of a "discounted" experience rather than a fully immersive one. I enjoyed that characters speak in their associated language, even though it broke the flow at times since it looks like everyone knows how to talk in about every language. Like when [b]Heihachi[/b] speaks in Japanese and [b]Nina[/b] says in English. 

[h1]An Intricate Dance with Your Opponent [/h1]
The fights in the game are dynamic; they can be fast-paced or have a slow tempo depending on each player's action. It is an intricate dance as [b] TEKKEN[/b] focuses more on figuring out your opponent in 3 rounds. It is about figuring out how your adversary thinks. The more you can predict and adapt on the fly to their play style, the better you will do. Some combos can be extended with walls or [b]Rage Arts[/b] to deal more damage. Also, each character has particular moves, such as projectiles, gap closers, dodging attacks, or movements that cannot be interrupted.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2118895889

Graphically speaking, [b]TEKKEN[/b] leaves something to be desired. Characters' hair can, at times, look bad. At the same time, its visuals fail to impress, feeling more like a title from an older generation. The game carries out as a service with content that is being added to it so. Still, there are titles of the same category looking better. I wish they would have thoroughly worked on this aspect to utilize its stages and character customization.

[h1]Music that Breathes Air and Fire[/h1]
Something I see few people talk about is the fantastic soundtrack that [b]TEKKEN[/b] has. The music is outstanding as it pumps you up, reflecting the energy of combat. Its weight is noticeable as its rhythm changes during the last rounds to exhibit the emotion of the fight. It goes even beyond that as it creates an environment for the players. An example is fan-favorite [b]Infinite Azure[/b], which is harmonic and a track perfect for listening to while in training mode, developing one craft. Meanwhile, [b]Heat Haze[/b] gives the aura of a "final battle" or "betting everything" with the high pumping, melodic singing, and explosiveness of the song!

Customization is another excellent aspect of [b]TEKKEN[/b]! The only thing I noticed that I didn't like is that all items are locked to [b]Treasure Battle.[/b] The mode itself could be better, as it can become pretty stale quickly as you only fight versus the CPU. Getting clothes and accessories to make your characters stand out more becomes tedious grinding. It can serve as some practice in the meantime, and the modifiers are fun at first, but my interest in it died out quickly as it was tedious at best.

[h1] Strong and Weak Points[/h1]
The strong point of this title, in addition to all the gameplay elements, is customization. While, as stated before, the grinding can be tedious, the options at the player's disposal are limitless! From butterfly wings to having a [b]Jenga[/b] on top of your head that keeps crumbling every time you are hit. They can give birth to some incredible characters and glamour and personalize them to your taste. Whenever you want to make your golden warriors, cute fighters, or the most strange ideas, there is a lot to try, and it is a lot of fun!

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2118897082

The weak point of [b]TEKKEN[/b] is the barrier for newbies to enter the game. It is easy to get into but hard to master, and the depth of its combat, combos, and characters can be too much for a newer player to wrap their head around. It doesn't help that it has an arcade formula, meaning that there are few flashy moves or assists in helping newbies. There is nothing wrong with any of those elements. It might be daring for newcomers, and lacking tutorials doesn't help. 

[h1]X Notes[/h1]
A fascinating aspect is that rather than making a new entry into the game, [b]Bandai Namco[/b] opted to carry it out as a service and kept adding content. There are guest characters such as [b]Noctis[/b] from [b]Final Fantasy XV,[/b] and [b]Negan[/b] from the [b]Walking Dead[/b] while favorites such as [b]Ganryu[/b] come back! In addition, extra modes and customization options are released as DLC, along with stages. 

Acquiring all of that content can be pretty pricey. For a total of $80, it is quite a high price for all of it. Characters have different prices assigned to them, with guest characters being a bit more expensive. At the same time, modes such a [b]TEKKEN BOWL[/b] can cost the same as up to 3 additional characters while being lacking. They also made the terrible decision of locking frame data behind a paywall, as you have to pay to unlock it when it should have been free. 

The game ran well on a GTX 1060 with an Intel Core i7-8750H resulting in a locked 60FPS with the setting set to max and the render scale of 200%; there are three different season passes.

[h1] Finally‚Ä¶[/h1]
[b] TEKKEN 7[/b] is a fantastic game if you are looking for a fighting game with a lot of depth and are okay with learning and practicing your craft to perfect it. It is more demanding than its peers in the dedication that needs to be put into it. Still, with a lot of content on the base game plus the DLC and the online being solid, it is a good buy for anyone interested in it and for fans of fighting games. If you want to get into the genre for the first time, consider other options or get into it with a lot of patience. A great game overall, with a lot going for it despite some failed decisions; I had a good time with [b]TEKKEN 7![/b]

I am a 44 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently downloaded Tekken 7 and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The game is missing some essential multiplayer features such as same rank player match, anti-cheat, "good" rollback, wifi vs cable players, cross platform compatibility, and punishment for alt+f4 abusers.
A big problem with cheating and alt+f4 abusers is that, all player data is stored locally and not in the cloud. This allows cheaters to manipulate their data using a cheat engine. Cheaters can basically change their rank, number of wins and "disconnect rate," and banco doesn't really care. 

So why should I spend time in practice mode to git gud if I can't trust that my opponents are playing fairly? And it's not like Tekken 7 is not selling well. It's one of the highest grossing fighting games of all time. That's in addition to frame data as DLC and DLC characters being released in a broken state to prioritize sales over balance.
I hope Tekken 8 fixes these issues or else I probably won't be able to play it.

I haven‚Äôt played Tekken 7 since its initial console release back in 2017 and I've had a lot of fun returning to it. I am rusty and not very good at it, but it is fun. I recommend the game to anyone who has a passing interest in the series. There are lots of characters, plenty of them are paid DLC and I would recommend waiting for sales, but there is a nice variety and they all represent different types of fighting styles. From boxing to taekwondo, you will easily find someone who fits your play style.

The single player content is adequate, but nothing truly special. The main story is a standout but there is some repetition at points. I don‚Äôt really care that much for the story of Tekken, but from a gameplay perspective, having me play Heihachi three separate times felt unnecessary and the ‚Äúkill x amount of continually spawning Jack‚Äôs and guys with guns‚Äù scenario was a little overplayed. As a casual observer of the overarching narrative of Tekken, I really could not care about what was actually happening between the fighting and I was fine with this. I just wanted an excuse to beat up a few CPU opponents and the game delivered.

The online modes (when they work, that is) are generally fun and the core gameplay is solid and entertaining at any skill level.

I think you should buy it, but here are a few small things I think are worth noting before you take the plunge:

The tutorial is unsurprisingly bad. It doesn't really exist at all and there are practically no systems to guide less experienced players, if you are entirely new to Tekken you will need to google basic information. It is easy enough to find online but I hope Tekken 8 takes steps forward to address this.

The game also has a fairly steep learning curve. There are lots of characters and even more impressively, they managed to map dozens and dozens of moves to just 4 action buttons. There are several characters that have move lists that are double, sometimes triple the standard in other fighting games. In some ways, the game having only 4 instead of the traditional 6 button layout makes it less technical on a very superficial level, but do not be deceived by this. The game is actually pretty demanding and complex in ways that other fighters are not, even more so when you consider this is a 3D fighter and you can move into the foreground. I did spend a bit of time in training to memorise the move list for my character to do basic punishes, but knowing how these moves interact and how they can snuff out other players moves is equally important. It is demanding and it can be overwhelming, even for the best of players. I actually like the technical nature of Tekken, but it might be a turn off if you can't invest a lot of time to learn the intricacies of both your own character and others. Knowledge is everything in any fighting game, but even more so in Tekken when compared to other contemporary fighting games.

In the brief amount of time I played ranked matches, there was also a huge amount of smurfing. This is where more experienced players use alternative accounts to game the system, specifically to fight newcomers who they can obviously obliterate in under 12 seconds each round because they‚Äôve already spent hundreds or even thousands of hours playing Tekken 7.

I don‚Äôt have any evidence that this is widespread and I could‚Äôve been a bit unlucky, but it was a common enough issue that I think it‚Äôs worth mentioning. You will likely come across players in the beginner league that have far greater experience than you do, which will make fights feel unfair at times. It probably doesn‚Äôt help that the game is several years old now and is probably front loaded with experienced players in the highest leagues the games offers, thus reducing the chances of coming across genuinely new players. It sucks and smurfing ruins the spirit of competition but there isn‚Äôt anything practical that can be done about it at this point in time, just get ready for a world of pain and be patient if you plan on playing ranked matchmaking. I hope Tekken 8 also takes steps to reduce smurfing when it eventually comes out.

Tekken 7 is otherwise a pretty good fighting game and is easily worth playing, especially if you have friends to play it with.

Tekken 7 matchmaking does not have:
- Placement matches or provisional ranks.
- Rank floors.

Tekken 7 matchmaking does have:
- LOCAL save data for online rank.
