Tekken 7 is a great game, but in a bad shape. To make this review look neat, I have organized it into bullet points.


**Story: The Mishima Saga & Character Episodes**

Good: 
  - The story has some cool fight scenes.
  - In many fighting games, the way the characters start a fight feels awkwardly forced. In Tekken 7, it has an interesting 
    and a unique way to start a fight. My favourite ones are when Akuma VS Kazuya on the G.Corp Helipad stage (Day) and 
    Heihachi VS Kazuya in the Brimstone and Fire stage.
  - Story CPU characters and enemies can be quite challenging if you try the story on the hardest difficulty. Shin Akuma on 
    the other hand...
  - The has some emotion because you can actually feel some sympathy when Heihachi he killed Kazumi. This is a good 
    thing because Tekken 6's story mode (Scenario Campaign) lacked by a lot.
  - It is neatly organized into chapters with interesting titles.
  - Some of the character episodes in this game are good, the rest...
  - Best part; You get to relive the intro from Tekken 5 and can actually play the destroyed Honmaru temple while fighting 
    the JACK-4 squad (Which also explains why JACK-4 was not a playable character in Tekken 4).

Bad:
  - The story was short, more could have been done.
  - The narrator made the story so boring, I couldn't last a second by listening to the narrator. Imagine someone in real says 
    this to you, in such a monotone and robotic voice, "My home got burnt to the ground and family died in the war".
  - Most of the character episodes are short and terrible.
  - Shin Akuma is annoying to fight against.
  - Some of the characters like Jin and Lars had less screen time because it was all focused on Heihachi and Kazuya.
  - Kazuya, my favourite character, had terrible writing.
  - The DLC characters, except Eliza, do not have an ending.


**Online**

Good:
  - The first Tekken game to have a rematch option.
  - The first Tekken game to have an online tournament mode.
  - The first Tekken game to have a rank points system (added in season 2).
  - We have suffered in past for not having rematch option and rank points system, so it is a blessing to have these features.
  - Tekken Prowess (added in season 4) encourages you to try other characters to increase your prowess.
  - Internet Indication (added in season 4) can allow players to see if their opponents are using an Ethernet cable or or WiFI.
  - The camera system has a unique way of allowing players to play on one side. For example, if both players are playing on 
    the same side, the camera system will adjust both of your screens for enhanced playability.
  - On the online VS screen, you can see the player's stats like Rage Usage, Combo Damage, Aggressiveness, etc.
  - The colour of your name changes, depending on your Tekken Prowess.

Bad:
  - The netcode is bad.
  - When an opponent disconnects on the online vs screen, that opponent will jump straight to the menu while you're stuck 
    on the vs screen for an eternity.
  - No actual consequences for disconnecting. Giving a penalty is nothing. At least Street Fighter V is doing something 
    about this.
  - No dedicated servers, considering that this game was made on a small budget. This is all due to the commercial failure 
    of Tekken Tag Tournament 2.
  - For some reason, your online rank, not being saved in an online sever, but on your hard drive where it contains files that 
    requires no encryption. What this means is that if you get demoted online, you can backup your rank by copy-pasting 
    your old save file into a new one and you'll get your rank back like nothing, as if your previous losses never happened. 
    We call this "safe-scumming".
  - When an opponent disconnects during a match, in an online tournament, either you win by default, or the whole 
    tournament gets disbanded.
  - Online is filled with hackers, cheaters and boosters.
  - Online leaderboards are definitely contaminated with boosters and fake ranks.
  - The online waiting room has no options for practice like in offline practice mode and you cannot pick a stage of 
    your own choice. Instead, you will be playing in an infinite stage (similar to the online waiting room in Tekken Tag 
    Tournament 2) and the music the same from the Geometric Plane stage.
  - The host of an online player session room should have the ability to choose which opponent to fight.
  - For some reason, you cannot back out of the character select screen in online after picking a side. All you can do is pick 
    a character, exit out of online training and will be directed back to the online menu mode.


**Offline**

Good:
  - Practice mode has a lot of options like punishment training (added in season 3).
  - Playing Treasure Battle allows you to unlock items.
  - Inputs can be shown for Rage Art and Rage Drive on the offline versus screen.

Bad:
  - Arcade mod is lacklustre. It only has five stages to complete.
  - The AI is weak, which makes Arcade and Treasure Battle boring.
  - Missing game modes like Survival and Team Battle.
  - General lack of offline modes.


**My Replay and Tips**

Good:
  - You can see replays of your previous battles and learn from your losses.
  - Has a lot of options like input display, frame data, attack info, etc., while watching your replay.
  - Replays can be saved.

Bad:
  - It was added in season 3. We had to wait for a very long time for this feature to be added.
  - Regular replays and saved replays get deleted after an update.


**Customization**

Good:
  - Ability to customize the border of the healthbar.
  - Character panels can be customized further and can be seen on the online VS screen.

Bad:
 - Poor character customization.
 - Most of the characters panels are awful.
 - Lacks a lot of options like decals from Tekken Tag Tournament 2 and many options of clothing from Tekken 6. Thankfully, 
   we have mods for that.
 - Healthbar customization should have had more options.


**Gallery**

Good:
  - Contains artwork and short music video clips (PACHI Slot) you have likely never seen before.
  - You get to watch character endings and look at artwork from previous Tekken titles.

Bad:
  - No option for pausing, going backwards or fast-forwarding when watching the cutscenes If you exit out of a curscene by 
    mistake, you will be taken back to the beginning. Just watch the endings on YouTube.


**ULTIMATE TEKKEN BOWL**

Good:
  - Relive the memories of playing Tekken Bowl from Tekken Tag Tournament.
  - A lot of fun.

Bad:
  - This mode should have been made for online as well.


**General**

Good:
  - The music is amazing
  - The new combo extender, referred to as 'screw' or 'tailspin', makes the combos more fun than 'bound' from Tekken 6. 
    Bound from Tekken 6 still exists, but the new combo extender makes your combos look better.
  - The graphics look amazing.
  - The first Tekken to be on PC.
  - The first Tekken to have controller setup on the character select screen.
  - Controller setup is way better and easy than in previous Tekken titles.
  - Unique character intros occur when you pick specific characters (e.g, Kazuya VS Kazumi or Akuma VS Jin/Devil Jin).
  - The first Tekken to have guest characters like Geese Howard from Fatal Fury/King of Fighters, Noctis Lucis Caelum from 
    Final Fantasy and Negan from the TV series; The Walking Dead.
  - Akuma and Geese look better in Tekken 7 than in their original games.
  - The first Tekken to have frame data display.

Bad:
  - No tutorial
  - Fight money can be used to unlock customization items and content from the gallery. But once you unlock everything, 
    the fight money is completely useless.
  - If you do not want to use fight money, you can still unlock everything by playing nearly 2,000 matches in total.
  - OG characters are locked behind a paywall.
  - Frame Data was added in season 3 and you have to pay for it.
  - Akuma and the rest of the DLC characters are broken.

Before You Buy

Tekken 7 is an excellent game with character designs, gameplay, and overall depth. A legendary series and its quality is still unmatched in 3D fighters. The game offers a wide range of characters to choose from. Each character has a distinct feel and playstyle. The roster has hundreds of moves and is capable of rich player expression. There are great in-game learning tools (replay system/punishment training) and plenty of guides to watch online. Other than these positives, there are significant drawbacks to consider.

-The Netcode of this game is not the best. Connection issues are common. You will be dealing with lag at times. 

-Also, please consider some people love to "plug" (disconnect) whenever they lose a heated battle. So they don't lose points while losing credibility. (The game scores a player's disconnect rate. You can see it before you get into a match with them.) Double-checking before accepting players who have a high disconnect rate should do it. (Anything above %2.0 if you ask me.)

-You'll feel hopeless at times. After facing smurfs / literal cheaters (auto block/auto punish etc.) and lag cheaters (lag created by the opponent whenever you attack or have to defend a throw). 

-Although in quick and ranked matches, players won't see their opponent's name until both parties accept the matchup. There are three indicators to distinguish players from one another before getting into the match. The indicators are Region / Language / Disconnection Rate. These could help you to avoid certain matchups or players in your play session. Said regions have six colors (red, blue, yellow, purple, pink, and grey).

-Until you learn how to deal with them, characters with gimmicky moves, mashers, and spammers will test your mental endurance.

Even if you survive this unpleasant environment and keep playing (especially) ranked mode, I have one last thing to share.

-After hitting "Ruler Ranks" (17th / 20th rank) you will most likely be facing top-ranked (29th / 30th rank) players who want to rank up their side characters. The first reason is they play the game more than other players do. The second reason is when you hit the highest rank, every other character you haven't played will jump to ruler ranks automatically. This scaling works on lower-ranked players as well.

Hopefully, Tekken 8 will resolve most of these issues. 

Still, Tekken 7 can be an incredible experience if you match up with people who have some dignity or whenever you play with your friends for fun <3

Tekken 7 is the ultimate fighting game that every true fighting game fan must try. With its impressive graphics, smooth gameplay, and diverse roster of fighters, Tekken 7 delivers an experience that is nothing short of electrifying.

The game features a plethora of characters, each with their own unique fighting style and special moves, giving players endless possibilities for strategizing and mastering their skills. And with the new addition of characters like Leroy Smith, Zafina, and Fahkumram, the roster keeps expanding and offering new exciting matchups.

What really sets Tekken 7 apart from other fighting games is its emphasis on precision and timing. Every move, every hit, and every block requires perfect execution and split-second decision making, making the game challenging and rewarding at the same time.

But Tekken 7 is not just about the fighting. It also features a deep and engaging story mode, where players can follow the story of their favorite characters and unravel the mysteries behind the Mishima clan's feud.

All in all, Tekken 7 is a masterpiece that every fighting game fan should have in their collection. Its polished gameplay, stunning visuals, and incredible attention to detail make it an unforgettable experience.

[Review after 100% completion]
The game can be a lot of fun, I think it best suits someone who enjoys practicing combos over and over. There is good character customization with lots of unlockables. If you are a completionist it's gonna be a long journey. Some of the achievements are not so bad, but the one requiring you to win an online tournament will require skill, and luck for getting that many people to play.
[Original first impressions review]
Four hours in and I have laughed more and had more tense moments than I have in many other games in recent years. Buy this if you like battle versus games. The combos are complex and take a great deal of time to master which is exactly what I love.

Few cons to be aware of, you must play during peak times to get a good online match flow, otherwise you could wait a while.
You need a good internet connection.

Tekken 7 is an absolute masterpiece of a fighting game that I have thoroughly enjoyed playing. The game's stunning graphics, engaging storyline, and smooth gameplay mechanics make it stand out as one of the best games in its genre.

However, the only issue I faced while playing Tekken 7 was the signal matching in online multiplayer mode. Despite having a good internet connection, there were often problems with network matching, leading to lag and disconnections. This can be frustrating, especially when you're in the middle of an intense battle.

Tekken 7 is an outstanding fighting game that offers a complete and immersive experience for both fans of the genre and newcomers alike. The game boasts stunning graphics that truly bring the characters and their respective fighting styles to life, making each battle a visually captivating spectacle.

One of the game's standout features is its diverse roster of characters, each with their own unique moves and backstory. Whether you prefer classic fighters like Kazuya Mishima and Heihachi Mishima, or newer additions to the series like Josie Rizal and Shaheen, there's a character to suit every playstyle.

The fight scenes in Tekken 7 are nothing short of incredible, with fast-paced, fluid action that is both thrilling to watch and exhilarating to play. The game's mechanics are easy to grasp, yet offer plenty of depth and nuance for players who want to master the game's more advanced techniques.

But Tekken 7 isn't just about the fighting ‚Äì it also boasts a compelling story that ties the characters and their motivations together in a cohesive and engaging way. The game's narrative is told through a series of cutscenes and character interactions, making for a truly immersive storytelling experience.

Finally, the game's controls are top-notch, offering precise and responsive input that allows players to execute even the most complex moves with ease. Whether playing on a console or a PC, the game's controls are intuitive and easy to learn, yet offer plenty of room for skill development and mastery.

Overall, Tekken 7 is a must-play game for fighting game fans, offering a wealth of content and an incredible fighting experience that is both visually stunning and mechanically engaging. Highly recommended!

I have been a tekken series fan since Tekken 3 ,Im writting this to let people know what you guys will encounter in this game that has been a real deal and a real Issue in Online Ranked :

1-Cheaters
Various of players cheating Using Scripts, Macros,and prb Software that conflict with in game Play
You will face players with 80 wins and no Looses ,Players that can Perfectely Backdash ,Combo u and Parry u.Players who mess with your Inputs, delay them , freeze them ,predict them.
There are going to be Players that could Make your gameplay lagg and in the end the get the Win out of it etc.

2-Pluggers 
Rage Quiters , that unplug their Network Connenction so they wont loose against u in real matches and could save their ranked Points from demoting them.They get a Penalty out of it But nothing too serious to make them quit of doing it again.  

3-Communication Error
You would encouter this type of error during Online extendeed matches with the prb beeing Various from Internet adapters , opponent misscommunication , etc . It will keep u waiting there for 5mins Synch Looping till eventually takes u back to Lobby

4-Lack Of Players In Tekken God , Prime and Omega Ranks
Matchmaking will make u wait in a lobby for a lott of minutes till it finds a player on those ranks to Match with. Prb beeing that less and less people reach this High Rank in this Game making the playerbase small and inactive.

5-Balacing Its A Huge Disaster
A lott of people will say that This may be a skill Issue ,but when it comes to DLC characters they have the Upper Hand when it comes having the worst balance of this game.Frames a lott of times are something to deal with as well. Balancing and Combo dmg is crazy ,Characters do 80% hp dmg leaving u with that 20 left in a single Combo but wise Balaning its better than past Tekken Games .

Do i reccommend this Game ?

Well as a hard fan and a Casual Player Tekken 7 is a very Competitive game that for new people in the series would make them confused and quit this game because of lack of starter wise Gameplay. The Story for me is a 10/10 but when it comes to starters mashing buttons will do its work but eventually they will get bored because  of inexperience.A Lott of people would want to learn how to play and practice mode is just perfect for them but in the end it isnt as ez and appeling to the Starter Eye.Menus are Complicated and one of the essential features the Frame Graph that needed to be Free ,so starter players can learn the game curve ,u have to pay for it.
In the end i would totally reccommend this game to play it ,but before u do so try do some research to see if u are innterested in . (I Wouldnt reccommend buy it as Tekken 8 its around the Corner ,Money Wise)

Even tough I am a little nostalgia-biased for playing quite a lot of Tekken 3 on the PS1, I have to say that the Tekken series is my favorite of the fighting game genre. 

Tekken 7 is not an exception, in fact, is what it got me back on the series. Sure it has some issues like limited customization when looking at T6 or TTT2 or longer loading screen between matches than the modern standard on other fighting games but the complexity and the pure fun factor of the game play is too engaging to care for these details. The never-ending learning of the extensive move list, screw combos, wall combos, wall carry, etc is very entertaining. Online play is still alive and the community is good, like any other game it has it's share of ragequitters, pluggers, and other types of troll-like personalities but also very nice people that will help you improve. Overall a very good experience and certainly, the gold standard of 3D fighting games for me.

[h1]Tekken 7[/h1]

If I could blast you with my Null Ray for not buying Tekken 7 already, I would! But alas, I cannot. i[/i] Seriously though, why are you even reading this? Get the game already! This is a monumental masterpiece.

[h1]GRAPHICS[/h1]

HOLY SCRAP! ARE YOU KIDDING ME RIGHT NOW?? FOUR Ks? FOUR! That's - KKKK! (No offense intended to our Cybertronian brethren). This game looks absolutely gorgeous! The shadows and lighting effects are just mind-blowing. Sparks fly everywhere when you land a powerful attack, and the level of detail on character clothing, hair, and other effects is simply incredible.

[h1]SOUND[/h1]

Imagine if you trapped lightning in a bottle, and every time you execute an electric wind godfist, that bottle opens up for a moment. If you don't have quadraphonic-prologic dolby surround pound, then you need to get it! Every punch to the face, every kick to the gut, you can feel the impact! [i](transforms and fires his Null Ray for emphasis)[/i] DOOOYAAA - DOOYAAAA - CRACKLE CRACKLE! Stage music is sick as usual, and if you want to pause the game and get down to some grooves while doing house work, then no problem! It's a piece of cake.

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]

Didn't I already mention the lengths gone to balance this thing out? THIS GAME IS TIGHT! What's that? Street Fighter has three or four moves per character? Pffft, forget that noise, boy! This game has like a hundred moves EACH!? And you can reverse every move! YOU CAN EVEN REVERSE A REVERSE! [i](laughs maniacally)[/i] "Chicken!"

[h1]REPLAY VALUE[/h1]

HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA! [i](transforms and flies around in excitement)[/i] Sorry, thought that was a joke. This game will easily have the most hours on my Steam account a month from now. It's so competitive that if all you want to do is get better and better, you will never get bored. In fact, most people who have already bought this game probably played the last Tekken up until last night. If they did not, then they lack discipline.

[h1]STORY[/h1]

I'm not going to say anything about the actual story itself, spoilers and all that jazz, but trust me, it's really good. It has a great dark tone that fits perfectly with the game. And if you know Tekken, you know Namco takes a lot of time making cutscenes and doing voice acting. This is top-notch stuff as far as fighting games go.

[h1]AKUMA[/h1]

Damn straight, he has his own heading! What the frag, how is he even here? He's so badass that Street Fighter couldn't contain him! Obviously, Asuka reached out to her ex, Akuma, when her current man, Heihachi, was mistreating her. Now, even though Akuma has no time for a woman's fragging nonsense - hence why he gapped in the first place to go to the mountains to train - he couldn't tolerate a woman being mistreated, hence his arrival. In fact, I wouldn't be surprised if Kazuya was Akuma's son. It makes sense! Why else would Heihachi throw him into a volcano? And how else would Kazuya survive? Of course he's Akuma's son! Kazuya's Devil Gene is actually pure Satsui no Hado, and that's why he's so powerful. Are you scared yet? You should be! Because with Akuma's presence, things just got even more intense in Tekken 7. So what are you waiting for? Get this game now and experience the power of Akuma for yourself!

OLD REVIEW:

I will continue playing, since I do like the game. But it has 3 major flaws that should keep you away. Don't waste your money until they fix them.

1. Locally stored rank, so smurfs can delete their high ranks whenever they would like and grief people still learning.

2. Not being able to enter practice mode with DLC characters to learn counters is a move to grab money with no concern to the player. I have no interest in playing the characters, but I can only practice when I see them online.

3. No penalty vs rage quitters.

As someone that is interested in learning, both of these things would be valid excuses in me quitting. I don't rage quit, and I've never saved my rank file to reload after a loss. I don't because that is the point of a rank. To earn it, not cheese it.

And also in the interest of learning, they require you to pay full price for characters to practice against even when you have no intention of playing them. I only play 1 character, and if I want to take the DLC ones to matches, I understand paying. But not for practice mode. I tweeted at the director when he was in Q&A, no reply. It is very selfish thinking on their behalf.

Don't spend money until they earn it, because you will just get frustrated losing progress to people with thousands of hours of experience.
Honestly it bothers me how many offline gamemodes are missing like Survival, Team Battle and Time Attack. But this is imo the best fighting game available on PC.

Tekken 4 was the best, literally fight me about it!..... Tekken has gone down hill since the release of Tekken 6. It's not "Tekken" anymore. Making Street Fighter X Tekken put the finishing nail it. We all wanted Tekken X Street Fighter because let's be real here for the a moment, it would have been a better game. It would have open the door to becoming the ultimate fighting game, but instead took an easier route so they could fuel the babies. Adding someone like Bob was a insult. This used to be about actual fighting styles that made sense not only to the character but you know the people playing it. Lets remove a real Muay Thai fighter {Bruce} and add a flimsy plastic barbie busty mock version to add diversity that wasn't needed {Joise} just as an example. Let's not even talk about the DLC characters because that's a slap to the face I don't need to acknowledge on all fronts of them from the old characters that should have been base to the wacky parallel universe this and most other fighting games have gone to.. Riddled with none sense over powered moves mixed with air juggling and ground pounding to the point where fighting doesn't seem fun anymore. Tekken always had these mechanics but was never defined by them and then made it the; most do or don't do at all mentality. Instead of fighting and just having fun and enjoying a nice brutal fight of strategy, it became a 1 shot wonder fandom reality for those who practice 1 singular combo and hope it works for them, even though there are sooooooo many combos and ways to chain them. If it's not a youtuber showing 1 shot methods it's must be lame. The Community is absolute swamp water. Do you think fight pads make a better fighter or does the 30% speed boost you get make you feel empowered? Does pulling the cord on a fight so you don't loss rank make you a smarter fighter or does running away like a digital Mayweather give you a sense of wellness? It must, because cheats like this plus auto block and counters, and players somehow being god tier at everything they do no matter the rank. I will crush a high ranking fight but loss in a low ranking fight like I've never even played the game before. Having a terrible previous record of fights but then comes crashing down on you like that wasn't a factor. Severe lag issues almost most fights that don't have a perfect connection rating. Hit Boxes are beyond my reason of thinking when you watch a mid attack scoop you off the ground like these people are professional dairymen. It's truly a shame too, because I have had some tremendous fights with some really cool random people, but as of right now those moments come fewer and fewer. Unless you like watching a great series turn to a pile of toxic **** stay away. I will have my eyes on Tekken 8 in hopes that they fix these issues and goes back to the king of fighters!!!

I don't know what exactly compelled me to try out Tekken 7, but I grabbed the Definitive Edition when it was on sale.

It was a worthwhile purchase, and I'm now excited for Tekken 8.

Great gameplay, an alluring soundtrack, lovely visuals, a robust netcode, a training mode equipped with frame data (that you had to buy, LOL), a replay feature where the game TELLS you what combos to use for max damage in certain situations, and a fantastic roster. All of these things go together for a great fighting game.

Fascinatingly, it even has a tutorial built inside the story mode. Although I personally would have preferred for the tutorial to have a mode all to itself, so it could offer more insight on the game mechanics than what is seen in the story.

And please, for the love of god, make the frame data part of the base package for ALL Tekken games going forward. That information is too valuable for the sake of learning how to use our characters to their fullest potential. Such a thing should NEVER be locked behind a paywall, low price or not. It's absurd.

The above aside, huge thumbs-up from me. If anyone wants some games, come take a swing at my Jin Kazama.

Since the dev focusing on competitive playerbase on making their contents and it really paid off making it the highest sale they've made for this series, they also sacrifice casual game contents that some would love to see. I would recommend this game if you leaning to play PvP games competitively. Most inaccessible fighting game on the market. 

* This game does not want new players. 20+ years of legacy mechanics and skill yet zero tutorial outside of loading screen tips you can easily miss. 
* Netcode sucks to the point where even two full-bar wired connections will lag and slow to a crawl. 
* Ranked system makes no sense in which you can beat someone 3 ranks higher and only get 80 points but lose to someone at your own rank and lose 1700. 
* The game and its players don't respect your time. Got about 500 hours between here and PS4 and the reception from others is "oh that's barely any time at all, you're still just starting out" from people who spent 2000 hours in practice mode alone just to perfect wavedashing and electrics.
* Community is toxic as hell and will send you hate messages for playing a character you like. 
* Only way to learn the depth of the game is to join Discord servers where those same jerkoffs that sent you hate messages are now posting swastika stickers and ascii art.  

It's not worth it. I'm not doing 1 hour drills every day in practice mode just learn backdash cancelling just to be able to basic movement to get out of pressure. I'm not going to dig through movelists to lab the handful of strings that are blowing me up: movelists are 80-100+ moves per character -- now multiply that by 50. That is asinine. I've done it all and it wasn't fun and any incremental improvement is overshadowed by getting stomped out by strings and set-ups you cannot visually see a counter for in the moment of the match.

Video games shouldn't be homework. You shouldn't have to do daily drills like it's some sports try-out. 

----

ps - can't wait for Tekken 8 to have the same netcode since Harada is a crotchety old man who gets praised for insulting the community and their issues with his game lol

I've been a Tekken fan my whole life & to see it become nothing but a grind is just saddening. There is next to nothing to actually do in game. Story mode has it's moments but is crap overall, characters don't have a proper arcade mode as all they get is a single fight with minimal thought & effort put into their bare-bone stories (that is if you can call them "stories"), barely any game modes (no survival, team battle, Tekken force, Tekken ball) & they don't allow you to do the special conditions seen in treasure battle in vs. mode (double damage, turbo mode, juggle battle). Speaking of treasure battle, it sucks. You get rewarded for fights with clothes & money, money that you'll most likely spend on clothes so what's the point? Especially when winning the fight itself gets you money. And the loading- oh, goodness gracious, the loading. Despite the arena & my character staying the same, it takes forever to load in my new opponent. I spend more time on loading screens then I do playing the game & sometimes it even crashes during load screens.
I understand that after the commercial failure of Tag Tournament 2 the budget was lower but that's no excuse for the game to be this lacking in content. There IS a Tekken Museum in the game (which is the other place to spend your money) but what that means is they are relying on the content from past games to make up for the nothing in this one. The story blows so hard that I took it upon myself to write (non-publicly available) fan-fiction to make up for sad feeling I was getting every time I looked at the new & legacy characters in the character selection screen. The gameplay, as good as it might be, won't bring people back to it when the next game comes out unlike Tekken 3, 4, 5, 6, Tag 2 & to some people Tekken 2 & Tag 1.
The cross promotional stuff has been fantastic, though. Akuma: Not the 1st time we've seen Tekken & Street Fighter cross paths but still good, Noctis: A bit weird but that's what makes it great, Geese: Excellent, Negan: The same as Noctis but 10x & as a fan NJPW I really liked the shirts & seeing King do the Rainmaker, even if I think he should have referenced Suzuki Minoru as he works at NJPW & did the motion capture for King.

After long hours Tekken feels like chess, it has such an amazing learning curve that I hardly find any game apart from it, the only pain point is certain DLC character which has been created in a pay to win model, so any characters which requires deep understanding of the intrinsic mechanics of this game may have a hard time with certain DLC characters which sometimes even break the game, but for casual player like me, its fun and its satisfying, once a player has a certain skillset he wont stop unless its becoming even better.

Purchased this a while ago and must say  I'm very impressed! I was excited to see what the latest installment had in store as a longtime fan of the series, and it did not disappoint.

The updated graphics were one of the first things that drew my attention. Character models are extremely detailed, and the environments are stunningly rendered. It's as if you're in the middle of a high-stakes fight.

The gameplay is also excellent. The combat is fast-paced and intuitive, with many different moves and combos to learn. I particularly liked the addition of new mechanics like Rage Arts and Power Crushes, which add depth to the already complex fighting system.

But the roster of characters is perhaps my favourite aspect of Tekken 7. There's something for everyone among the over 30 fighters available, each with their own distinct playstyle and backstory. Whether you prefer fast characters like Hwoarang or hard-hitting powerhouses like King, you'll be able to find a fighter who matches your preferences.


Overall, I'd recommend Tekken 7 to anyone looking for a rewarding and challenging fighting game. The graphics are stunning, the gameplay is excellent, and the cast of characters is diverse and exciting. It's a must-play for any genre fan!

one of the best fighting games I've played

Everything is great except for ranked matchmaking

What the fuck is the whole point of the rank system if I keep getting matched up with someone who are far superior than me?
Also, why would the ranking based matchmaking based on the character rank?
Why not based the matchmaking on Tekken Prowess???
It makes no sense whenever I play ranked, the character I played is initiate, and I got matched with a character with the same rank, but have 150+ wins, with a far higher Tekken prowess than me in which, they are incredibly superior than me.
I genuinely don't get it.
It sucked so much.
Also, going back to the warmup lobby to find a new player is useless.

I lost 5 times in a row because I played with a Kazuya who was far superior than me so I decided to return to the warmup room or even go back to the online menu because I knew I have 0 chance of beating him, but got rematched with him again and again and again and lost a lot of my rank. I declined/cancel some of the upcoming matches because I was afraid that I'll be playing with that Kazuya again but guess what? He keeps coming back.
Like god damn how is that fair?
I don't blame this on the Kazuya but it's baffling that a system where I can choose to either battle the same person again or to go back to the menu/warmup room to find another opponent, fails to do what it meant to do.

Lastly, there's a weird system that idk if it's related to the ranked based matchmaking but everytime I won at least once, twice being the most, and I beat my opponent easily, the next match I got would be 1000x harder than before, once again, making it almost impossible to rank up

I'm no Tekken Pro, nor anything near it, I do suck, but why would you make a system that demotivate someone to get good? I want to play online and I want to get good, but this terrible system confuses me. I don't know if I'm actually good because I just beat two players very easily, or am I bad because the next 5 matches I'm totally  F  U  C  K  E  D.

Update: easy to say that this game have the worst matchmaking I've ever experienced. Imagine yourself playing Geese Howard, Brawler Rank, your Tekken Prowess is 60k+, and you play pretty well get a few wins, then instantly get matched up with a Grandmaster King but have 20 wins (meaning that the King played insanely good because he's on a win streak) and his Tekken Prowess is 100k+(meaning that the player playing that King is just good in general and have superior experience and skill not in playing King, but in Tekken in general)....Like, HOLY SHIT THE MATCHMAKING IS TOTAL GARBAGE.
As I said, why tf is the matchmaking based on the character rank??? And not based on Tekken Prowess? It's totally pointless. A really good player that has been playing for a long time might try out a new character and (obviously) have an Initiate Rank but of course, since they probably already play for a long time, they probably have an easier time understanding the character they're playing, as well as playing the character in general even though it's their first time playing said character. Thus it's almost impossible for me to beat that player. It's so absurd. I'd rather play with someone who is equal to me, then we keep rematching one another, having a win-lose cycle and leads to me going up and down in ranks. If that's the case at least it's fun. If any of you reading this might say that I'm just trash, it's because I am. I'm not a complete trash, I still know how to punish, do combos and even create combos, but the players I played against are insanely skilled in various ways. From learning Korean Backdash, rapid sidestepping and even do death combos.

So is this game good? Yes it's a masterpiece, 10/10 best game ever made. Flawless. Would recommend. Truly, one of the games of all time.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Tekken 7 approaches the level of Tekken 3 in terms of balance and sophistication - and with the enduring similar quality of other successful fighting games, yet remains the Iron Fist in the genre.

Here's a snippet of gameplay on the steam deck: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bxKqdKtRt34

In this seventh part the conclusion of the Mishima saga is told. The story is told through a reporter and you also play the story mode with characters that the story is being told about.
It all starts quietly through some kind of introduction where it started.
Little Kazuya is pissed because Heihachi killed his mother.

When you are done with the story mode there is another mode where you can perform a player story battle.
These are short fights of 2 rounds against a rival from the series. Jin vs Hwoarang for example.
For example, these fights have a short intro with a small cut scene and you no longer have to defeat 10 or 20 enemies to see the story per character.

Tekken 7 tries to make up for its lack of a superlative single player with sophistication and nostalgia.
For example, the game lets you create playlists with the music from all previous Tekken games, for example.
And the Gallery is the biggest nostalgia bomb since a Smash Bros. game; for example, I really enjoyed watching all Tekken 3 ending movies a little too much.

Another smaller addition to the combat system is the Power Crush.
These are normal attacks, but with one big advantage: they are not interrupted by high and mid attacks.
So the only way to stop a Power Crush is to perform a low attack or a roll.
Among other things, it made me stay a little closer to my opponent than usual, so that I could immediately perform a low kick or throw if I saw him or her perform a Power Crush animation.

When I was younger, I used to play Tekken on PS2 with my father that was a big part of our bonding time. But as I grew up and life got busy, we stopped playing together, and eventually, the game became just a memory. That is until I stumbled upon Tekken 7 and decided to give it a try.

I had no idea that this decision would change everything. As I played the game, memories of my childhood with my father came flooding back, and I was filled with nostalgia. I couldn't help but feel a little sad that those days were gone.

But as I continued playing, something amazing happened. My father saw me playing the game and was thrilled that I had picked it up again. He told me stories about our time playing together, and before I knew it, he was sitting next to me, controller in hand, and we were playing together once again.

Tekken was just as I remembered it, but now, playing it with my father, it was even better. We laughed, joked, and bonded over the game, just like old times. I felt like a kid again, and I could see the joy in my father's eyes as we played together.

It's amazing how a video game can bring people together. Tekken 7 not only allowed me to relive my childhood but also gave me the opportunity to reconnect with my father. The game is more than just a sequel; it's a symbol of the bond between a father and son.

Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants to relive their childhood memories and reconnect with their loved ones. For newcomers to the game, be prepared for a challenge, but don't let that discourage you. With persistence, patience, and a willingness to learn from mistakes, you'll find that the difficulty only adds to the satisfaction. And who knows, you might just find a new way to bond with a loved one

i genuinely have never played a game with an online system as completely and utterly broken as this. im not joking or exaggerating when i say that every single person that was tasked with making the online for tekken 7 should be blacklisted from the video game industry for the rest of their miserable gaping void of a life. if you have never played tekken and want to get good at it, wait for tekken 8 because you literally cannot do that in this game. if its not trolls spamming the exact same annoying string over and over again, forcing you to essentially lab that one single move the entire game instead of actually playing tekken, then its the most egregious smurfing i have ever seen in a video game (and ive played A LOT of online games with smurfing problems). unless you're willing to tank your disconnect rate and pull your ethernet cable every time you match into someone with 100+ more wins than you, you will not have fun and you will never improve. the ranking system makes it completely effortless to either reset your rank (since rank files are stored LOCALLY) or just switch to another character (since your rank is character based). this means that someone can play 500 matches of one character, switch to a different but similar character (kazuya->heihachi for example) and immediately be placed against people that have barely played the game. absolute fucking disgrace of game design and a complete waste of my money. i genuinely, from the bottom of my heart, DO NOT recommend you buy this game if you are new to tekken. the developers have made it clear that they care more about adding expensive and broken dlc characters to the game to leech money out of its playerbase than actually making a fun competitive experience for new players. they also nerfed sidestepping, the single most unique aspect of tekkens gameplay, so that most moves will still hit you while stepping, for the purpose of making the game (more accessible). despite this, they still made it extremely difficult to break throws (especially given the fact that their god awful rollback makes it impossible to hit the input even if you do expect it), encouraging more players to spam them against new players who will be more likely to not crouch or break them. this game is not worth buying or playing if you are not already good at tekken, and i can never get my time or my money back that i wasted on it. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

The first figher I have ever played competitively. Tekken 7 is praised to be the best of the series by many long time Tekken veterans. Coming into this game only every playing casually before, I was drawn to Hwoarang because I grew up watching my old mans brothers play him in Tekken 3, 4, 5, Tag, Tag2. So naturally. I became a Hwo main. 

Tekken is regarded by many as the most complex 3D figher out to date currently. That is an opinion that I believe I can stand behind, as the higher in the ranks you go, you realize, there is some kind of barrier you need to break. Whether that be, learning Frame Data, understanding a matchups magic 4, you never realized before, etc. If you play Tekken 7 competitively in the Ranked Mode, you will be in for many hours of enjoyment/frustration. The game will become a skill. It is seriously a skill that you hone and learn but what's amazing about Tekken, is every character is so deep with their own preferred playstyle, moveset, and character design that you will spend HOURS learning a second character. 
Then you glance at the whole roster. 

Learning how to play Tekken is like learning how to play music. Say you can play guitar, very well. you can play with a Trumpet, you know how to make it work, right. Lets say that guitar is your main character, and the trumpet is your opponent. You can play with the trumpet, but if you pick up the trumpet never have doing so before, youre gonna struggle playing.

Thats why I love Tekken.

EDIT:

One of the best if not the best fighting games to come out in the last decade. Extremely balanced with a good online component.

A STEAM Sale made this game extremely affordable otherwise, I would have not been able to afford it.

I bought the definitive edition for $20. 

It was a pretty good deal considering the definitive edition included all characters, all stages, and all DLC that would have costed me over $200 to get.

I think what happened is this company tried to pull of a "Street Fighter 5" trick. Where you buy the game and think you have a full game but find out everything is behind a paywall and you can't earn characters in game unless you put on a advertisement suit or watch ads in between fights.

Yeah, Capcom tried to pull that bullshit off.

It is why I am not expecting much from Street Fighter 6, but onwards to this game, they tried to pull the same shit off here by the fanbase of fighting games were already wise to the bullshit and didn't buy into this time.

Tekken 7 failed in my opinion because it had a HUGE paywall that kept players from enjoying their favorite fighters.

In the beginning, and yes I was around during the beginning of Tekken and was a huge game fanatic then, this game had all character unlockable through playing the game.

It was great. 

But... NOTHING has changed. The same clunky fighting style that we dealt with in the 1990s is being displayed 30 years later in Tekken 7.

I get it. New graphics, new types of fighting modes and online play, but the moves haven't changed in 30 years. The game has not really evolved much at all.

I am not saying it isn't fun in some way, but honestly I am sad to say I wasn't all that excited to play it.

You can just mash buttons and as long as you mash them first before your opponent you win.

I guess it is kind of comparable to playing a game of "whack a mole". 

It is kind of annoying a way when your opponent just juggles you in the air for 7 or 8 hits and you have already lost the match.

I am not saying it isn't fun buy the dynamic that you can simply juggle somebody in the air hit after hit just seems lazy.

If you compare it to Street Fighter 5 it is a no contest.

SF5 is probably the best fighting EVER RELEASED in the HISTORY of gaming. I shit you not, and you have to pay out of your ass for it. 

That sucks, and I won't so it again, but I CERTAINLY won't do it for a half ass clunky, air juggling, button mashing mess of a game like Tekken 7. 

I hope they do it better in Tekken 8, but I am going to doubt it.

I would recommend this game for $20, yes. But that is the only reason.

It is a good game to have in you library especially for those that grew up playing it. 

I only like this game for nostalgic reasons, but as a fighter game it just doesn't do it for me in the modern era.

But, get it anyways for $20. I don't know if the company that developed the game is in on the sale or in some way prompted it, but if they did I would take the olive branch to mean maybe they won't be so greedy in their monetization like they did here in their next game.

Here is too hoping that is lol.

More of an "eh" than a thumbs down. [i]Tekken 7[/i] is way too complicated and sweaty to enjoy online (where the opponent's latency is [i]law[/i]), but there's good, clean, arcade fun to be had locally with friends. Unfortunately, the full game with all characters unlocked is prohibitively expensive. As always with BAMCO fighting games, [i]Tekken 7[/i]'s price is wildly bloated by a scummy DLC/season pass structure.

It's what you expect from a Tekken game. Graphics are nice, soundtrack seems OK, and mechanics are fluent as always.

However, the Mishima Saga's final boss is b******* on hardest level. I get that it's supposed to be challenging, I knew it wasn't going to be easy, but it's completely unfaIr. Game doesn't follow its own rules, and if the boss gets to rage art, you lost.

Rage art is cool, but it seems like something ripped off from Mortal Kombat -games. And then the micro transactions. WHY is there lot of original characters locked away as DLC? Oh, and it costs 6$ per character to unlock.

Akuma is OK if you had to bring someone from the Street Fighter -franchise, but Ruy, Guile or Ken would have been awesome. Walking Dead guy and Final Fantasy characters are lame tbh. Oh, and they cost 8$ each to unlock.

Online battles with friends seems impossible due to all communication errors.

Despite all the negative side, it is still a proper Tekken game, which is awesome to play under the same roof with friends.

The fighting mechanics are deep and complex, allowing for endless strategic possibilities and highly satisfying combat encounters. The game's rich and complex story mode provides a compelling narrative that is sure to captivate players, while its wide range of modes, including online multiplayer, provide endless hours of fun and competition.

One of the standout features of Tekken 7 is its accessibility to both seasoned fighting game players and newcomers to the genre. The game features a robust tutorial system and helpful training modes that allow players to learn the ropes and hone their skills, while its depth and variety make it appealing to seasoned players looking for a challenge.

Overall, Tekken 7 is an excellent fighting game that offers a fantastic blend of action, strategy, and storytelling. Whether you're a seasoned fighting game player or a newcomer to the genre, this game is definitely worth checking out.

I love the Tekken series and I have been playing since the first one (I mainly play on the PS4 version). Tekken 7 is by far the most balanced it has ever been. Although a lot content is missing compared to previous titles, the gameplay is so smooth that it kind of makes up for it (just barely lol). I know its difficult, but learning the game is worth it (especially since Tekken 8 is on its way).

I hope everyone enjoys the game as much as I do!

Very fun. If you think Tekken 8 looks cool, give this one a shot, it goes on sale constantly. It will look very difficult in the beginning but once you get into it, I feel it is more rewarding than other fighting games. Choose a character that looks cool and play them, watch a guide on how their play style works etc. Do not get influenced by people saying this or that character is bad. They are mostly talking about professional levels of play. All characters can reach the highest online rank, what matters is the player.

Online has been good for the most part, and pretty populated, depending on where you live. For some reason however if your opponent alt+f4s you get stuck there loading forever. I don't understand why this happens. By the time you stop loading, the person who left has probably played a whole other match. Fortunately alt+f4s are rare. Unless you play Marduk.

Story is alright, I don't buy a fighting game for the story, but if you care about that, it's there.

Customization is ok. Some characters have a lot of creative potential, while others can only change colors, everything else looks bad. Not even mentioning the items that are shared for all characters. They all look terrible unless you're trying to make a "funny" customization.

Tournaments are good, the rewards could be better.

Offline mode is cool. Playing a character in treasure mode should only give you items for that character, or at least significantly raise the chances. I've played so many games as Julia trying to get a certain outfit, but keep getting stuff for other characters instead.

Training mode should have a lot more tutorials for newer players. Punishment training is a good start. Training should be teaching new players about fundamentals, when to use certain moves, wall breaks, floor breaks, counter hits, rage drives etc. You are free to train all of these things by yourself of course, but some guidelines would be nice.

The game itself could be better optimized. I can't count how many times the game crashed, because I alt tabbed during a loading screen and I have a pretty good PC.

Overall I definitely recommend this game. Don't buy it full price though, wait for a sale.

Regretful purchase. Tekken is one of my all-time favorite series, and this is one is a dog. The story mode is slow, painful, and  it's hard to skip through the many, many cut scenes. Also the load times are pretty slow. Fights go from being mind-numbingly easy to controller-throwing, rage-quitingly impossible (akuma vs Heihachi). This would be forgiven but the game mechanics seem to also be lacking features that I remember from way back in Tekken 3. That said, local VS mode with a bro is still fun. Just hoping the next installment is better!

This is by far the deepest and hardest fighting game I have ever played. The competitive community is huge.  At this point in the game's life cycle, it seems like the player base is comprised exclusively of hardcore players/competitors. 
If you love ultra competitive competition and a steep learning curve then Tekken 7 is definitely for you. The community is very helpful and there are tons of resources available to actually learn how to play the game.
Go ahead and purchase this game and dedicate 15+ hours per week to it. I promise you that you will not regret it :-)
